My vote in favour is based on the importance of the innovation of having an automatic emergency service that can reduce the risk of death and serious injury, thereby increasing European citizens’ safety on the Union’s roads.

 
  
 		 

  Véronique Mathieu (PPE), in writing. – (FR) I voted in favour of this resolution to fit all vehicles offered for sale in the European Union with eCall technology from 2015. Thanks to this Europe-wide system, we could save 2 500 lives a year and reduce the number of severe injuries arising from traffic accidents.

 
  
 		 

  Alexander Mirsky (S&D), in writing. – This is a very important resolution because in the event of a severe road accident, an eCall-equipped vehicle will automatically trigger an emergency call. All road users will benefit from that kind of equipment. I am in favour.

 
  
 		 

  Andreas Mölzer (NI), in writing. – (DE) The fundamental idea of an emergency service that calls the nearest public safety answering point automatically is a good one, but, as is so often the case, there are gaps in the idea which need to be closed before the system can be regarded as perfect. We live in an age when we can and must expect the highest standards in technological terms. I am of the opinion that every Member State should decide for itself whether it wants to fit this system in cars, because it involves certain risks. It is important to remember that there is a risk that the system will be activated in the case of every accident, even if it is ‘just’ a rear-end collision. When it makes a call, the emergency services will arrive and find out that there is ‘only’ damage to the vehicles and this may prevent them from reaching the scene of another accident in good time. We need to bear this in mind. Furthermore, the system should officially only be activated when it is needed, but it is difficult to establish this in advance. There is a risk of it being misused, even in stand-by mode. I see this as a breach of privacy, because the eCall system can be used to identify where people are and how fast they are driving, for example. For the reasons I have given, certain issues need to be rectified or reconsidered, which is why I have abstained.

 
  
 		 

  Claudio Morganti (EFD), in writing. – (IT) Every year in the European Union, road accidents give rise to about 40 000 fatalities, and more than 150 000 people suffer permanent disability as a result. These shocking statistics show us how dramatic the situation is and how important it therefore is to find ways of improving it. The report that we adopted today, and which I willingly supported, provides for the introduction of an automatic alarm system: when installed in a vehicle that has been involved in an accident, eCall will, in fact, send an alert concerning the event by making an encoded emergency call to the 112 number, which has now become the single European number for emergencies, valid, that is, in all Member States. Clearly, this will not help to prevent accidents, but it will certainly help rescue teams, for whom rapid and timely reaction is essential, to become more effective. Estimates indicate that it may be possible to save 2 500 human lives every year by means of this system. I hope that there will be many more than this, but in any case, every person that can be saved as a result of this system will nevertheless be a great success and an important result for everyone.

 
  
 		 

  Radvilė Morkūnaitė-Mikulėnienė (PPE), in writing. – (LT) I voted in favour. It is my view that from 2015, eCall should be installed in all new models of cars and light vehicles and should function fully throughout the EU, as well as in other European countries wishing to use it. In Lithuania alone, there are more than 6 000 car accidents each year, in which more than 8 000 people are injured and almost 700 killed. The introduction from 2015 of the eCall system in all cars in EU Member States would save 2 500 lives a year, while reducing the severity of injuries by 10-15%. The introduction of the eCall system in a new car would cost less than EUR 100, but the driver should not have to shoulder the financial burden and the eCall service must be free of charge. The system does not send any signals and is completely dormant until sensors detect that a serious accident has taken place and automatically transmit a signal, even if, following the accident, the driver or passenger is unconscious. It will also be possible for a person who has witnessed the accident to activate the system by pressing a button. Research shows that when this technology is applied, rescuers arrive 40% quicker in urban areas and 50% quicker in rural areas. It is regrettable that over the course of more than five years, the voluntary deployment of this system has not produced any results.

 
  
 		 

  Katarína Neveďalová (S&D), in writing. – (SK) More than 39 000 lives are lost and more than 1.2 million passengers are injured every year in road accidents across the EU. These alarming statistics point to the fact that road safety concerns all EU citizens. Our task is therefore to support proposals that would reduce the death rate in road accidents and would constitute a step forward in ensuring road safety. The eCall system is a modern, intelligent traffic safety system, the role of which is to automatically call the emergency services in the event of an accident without the driver, who may be injured or unconscious, having to lift a finger. The speedy and timely intervention of the emergency services is often crucial. In the case of serious injuries, every minute counts. The eCall system represents a major challenge for the transport policies of the EU Member States. In view of the time that the EU has spent since 2003 trying to develop a system in detail, it is high time for it to be finally harmonised across all Member States. The only downside may be the slightly higher costs when purchasing a vehicle, but one must realise that in mass production, it would be a marginal amount which is negligible compared to the number of lives saved.

 
  
 		 

  Rolandas Paksas (EFD), in writing. – (LT) I welcome this resolution. eCall is a vitally important system. In order to improve citizens’ living conditions and even save their lives, the emergency call system should be constantly expanded and improved. The full integration of this system would save thousands of lives each year. It is very important for the system to be used in heavy goods vehicles, as well as agricultural and industrial vehicles. Such vehicles are used in remote and isolated areas and drivers are sometimes unable to contact the emergency services in the event of an accident.

 
  
 		 

  Justas Vincas Paleckis (S&D), in writing. – I voted in favour of this report in order to strengthen the protection of European citizens.

The EU does so much for free movement within the Member States, and we have to make this movement safe. I regret that many Member States have not yet joined the eCall system. It is a joint project and all European citizens have the right to the same level of protection, regardless of their nationality. The improvement in the response of the European emergency services will permit up to 2 500 lives to be saved annually and to reduce the severity of injuries by 10-15%.

Therefore, I support the rapporteur, who calls on the Commission to make legally binding decisions on that issue. I join the colleagues who are concerned about respect for the privacy of the people who have the eCall system installed. The system should not be allowed to track the movement of cars. Only information on the exact place of the accident is necessary for intervention in case of emergency.

 
  
 		 

  Georgios Papanikolaou (PPE), in writing. – (EL) This particular report, which I supported, sets out practical applications and actions to reduce the number of road accident victims, in order to provide European citizens with better protection. For Greece, progress in efforts to use technology to identify and quickly rescue road accident victims has added value, given that Greece – together with Romania – recently broke the record for road accident victims (approximately 130 per million per annum). However, the 112 service has an exponential practical value when an accident occurs in an isolated, provincial location, where it is hard for victims to inform anyone of their location and situation.

 
  
 		 

  Maria do Céu Patrão Neves (PPE), in writing. – (PT) eCall is a mechanism to trigger automatically an emergency call in the event of a severe road accident. I voted for this report, as the economic benefits of this system and its positive impact on the sector have been studied, and because I believe the greatest benefit of the eCall system will be to reduce the number of fatalities and the severity of injuries caused by road accidents, since the emergency services will arrive at the scene of the accident faster.

 
  
 		 

  Aldo Patriciello (PPE), in writing. – (IT) The motion helps to improve the effectiveness of the emergency services by creating a voice connection with the nearest public safety answering point (PSAP) and sending an emergency message. The Commission decided in 2011 that it would take legislative action to make the introduction of eCall obligatory. In the hope that the number of road victims will decrease thanks to the swifter arrival of the emergency services at the scene of the accident, I am voting in favour of the motion.

 
  
 		 

  Paulo Rangel (PPE), in writing. – (PT) eCall is a European initiative, the main aim of which is to provide rapid assistance to motorists involved in road accidents across the EU. The implementation of the project involves installing a device in all vehicles which automatically calls 112 in the event of a road accident and transmits the coordinates to the competent authorities via GPS. eCall does not prevent accidents, but it does make the emergency services more effective. When the emergency services are promptly notified and know the accident location, they can arrive quickly and reduce the risk of death and the severity of injuries. I would stress that any added in-vehicle application based on the eCall telematics platform should comply fully with the relevant data protection and privacy regulations. I voted for this report for those reasons.

 
  
 		 

  Crescenzio Rivellini (PPE), in writing. – (IT) Today, during the part-session in Strasbourg, we voted on the report by Mr Koch and Ms Sehnalová. Parliament has come out clearly in support of all motorists in Europe, so that they can benefit from a free emergency call system. Given that the voluntary approach has failed to produce results, the Commission is being urged to put forward legislative measures as soon as possible to ensure that the eCall system becomes obligatory in all EU countries by 2015. In the resolution, the Commission is invited to consider the possibility of extending the system in the near future to other vehicles, such as motorcycles, buses, coaches and lorries. This system uses the technology of 112 emergency calls so as to automatically alert the emergency services of the location of the vehicle in the event of a serious accident, thereby saving lives, reducing the severity of injuries and also ensuring the arrival of qualified and fully equipped paramedics within an hour of the accident, under what is known as the ‘golden hour principle’. The eCall system will enable around 2 500 lives to be saved every year. It is also considered that the public eCall service should be obligatory and available free of charge to all drivers in Europe, regardless of the type of vehicle.

 
  
 		 

  Robert Rochefort (ALDE), in writing. – (FR) The aim of the in-vehicle eCall system is to ensure the automatic notification of the emergency services in case of a serious accident, allowing the emergency services to arrive faster at the scene and thus reduce the number of road fatalities and the severity of injuries. In Europe, over 40 000 people die each year in road accidents and 150 000 people suffer permanent disability. The installation of the eCall system in all vehicles in the Union would save the lives of 2 500 people each year and reduce the severity of injuries by 10-15%. This system must therefore be installed as soon as possible in Europe’s vehicles. In this resolution, Parliament calls for all new cars to be fitted with this device by 2015 and insists on the fact that this emergency call service should be free of charge and accessible to everyone. The resolution also provides guarantees on the use of the data, stressing that the eCall service cannot be used to monitor a person’s movements or determine his location unless that person has been involved in an accident. It has my support.

 
  
 		 

  Raül Romeva i Rueda (Verts/ALE), in writing. – Abstention. On the one hand, eCall could contribute to improving emergency services in certain cases. On the other hand, the Commission has so far refused to propose efficient measures on accident avoidance, such as stricter speed and alcohol limits. The Greens/EFA asked for more detailed information on the eCall infrastructure costs and who would pay them. We also asked for better measures on interference with eCall in terms of false or imprecise information in case of an accident. The answers were unsatisfactory and our amendments on these items were rejected.

 
  
 		 

  Licia Ronzulli (PPE), in writing. – (IT) I voted in favour of this document because I believe the proposal to equip all new vehicles with the eCall device by 2015 to be important. It will enable the rescue services to be alerted automatically in the event of a road accident by means of the public 112 emergency call service. In this way, it would be possible for the emergency services to arrive more rapidly; something that could save around 2 500 lives per year and also significantly reduce the severity of injuries sustained.

 
  
 		 

  Nikolaos Salavrakos (EFD), in writing. – I voted in favour of this report as, in the event of a severe road accident, an eCall-equipped vehicle will automatically trigger an emergency call. I believe that it proposes positive measures for the reduction of the number of fatalities and the mitigation of the severity of injuries caused by road accidents.

 
  
 		 

  Matteo Salvini (EFD), in writing. – (IT) I voted firmly for this report. European car manufacturers claim they are ready to take on the challenge of incorporating this type of equipment in the vehicles they produce. This will have the result of saving human lives. However, I should not like the European Parliament to go too far, perhaps by proposing to extend eCall to other types of vehicle too rapidly. In current circumstances, that would amount to excessive costs for manufacturers and would probably not have the effect of improving road safety. As regards ordinary cars, I remain in favour, and I hope that these devices will soon be launched on the market.

 
  
 		 

  Amalia Sartori (PPE), in writing. – (IT) Road safety is a subject of enormous importance, especially nowadays, when technology and developments in the automotive sector are reaching ever higher levels. The EU’s task is to adopt legislation that will enable citizens to travel on safe roads and in safe vehicles. That is why I voted for the resolution moved by Mr Koch and Ms Sehnalová on the adoption of the eCall system in all cars by 2015. The introduction of this device will bring many benefits. In the event of a serious accident, a vehicle equipped with eCall will automatically place a 112 emergency call, even if the passenger is not in a fit state to speak, and provide the emergency services with all the key information on the accident. Thanks to the use of this technology, about 2 500 lives will be saved every year and the severity of injuries sustained will fall by 10-15%, all due to the swifter and more efficient intervention of the rescue services at the scene of the accident.

 
  
 		 

  Vilja Savisaar-Toomast (ALDE), in writing. – (ET) The objective of eCall is to ensure the automatic notification of emergency services from inside a vehicle in the case of an accident, in order to reduce the number of casualties from traffic accidents and mitigate the seriousness of injuries sustained in traffic accidents. eCall will speed up the arrival of qualified and properly equipped assistance. The application of eCall technology must be compulsory and available to all drivers of vehicles in the European Union. It is also important that vehicles imported into Europe from third countries should be required to have eCall technology. eCall technology must be installed in all new cars. eCall technology is based on the 112 emergency number, and must be compulsory and free of charge for all. Parliament is calling on the European Commission to acknowledge the need to develop, by the end of 2012, a directive that would include the implementation of eCall. In order to mitigate the problems associated with the introduction of eCall, the Committee on Transport and Tourism and the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection have called upon Member States to cooperate with the European Commission to plan and implement national pilot programmes for the utilisation of the European in-car automatic emergency call system (eCall), in order to address all of the problems that may arise.

The infrastructure required for the eCall technology must also be created, and telephone operators must be provided with the training required to prepare them for the compulsory introduction of this system in all Member States by 2015. Based on the above, I supported the adoption of this report.

 
  
 		 

  Debora Serracchiani (S&D), in writing. – (IT) I voted in favour of the Sehnalová report on the establishment of the security system known as eCall, as I believe it is an excellent means of preventing road accidents and more. Thanks to this system, it will also be possible from now on to reduce the congestion caused by accidents, thus preventing more accidents from occurring. I regret the delays and the lack of progress in the voluntary deployment of eCall to date and I hope that all parties involved will act simultaneously in order to establish this service. I also believe there must be coordinated awareness-raising campaigns concerning the eCall system and its benefits for European citizens, with the aim of increasing both the understanding of, and the demand for, the service.

 
  
 		 

  Sergio Paolo Francesco Silvestris (PPE), in writing. – (IT) Since, according to the prediction made by the World Bank, the number of traffic accident victims is expected to rise in every area of the world, the European Union must face up to the problem. Currently, in Europe, based on 2004 data, more than 40 000 people die every year in road accidents and 150 000 suffer permanent disability. This vote will encourage the deployment of eCall; in the event of a severe accident, a vehicle equipped with this device will automatically trigger an emergency call. Even if the passenger cannot speak, eCall creates a voice link to the nearest public safety answering point and sends an emergency message, including key information about the accident, such as time, accurate location, driving direction (resulting from accurate satellite-based data) and vehicle description.

 
  
 		 

  Marc Tarabella (S&D), in writing. – (FR) This vote in favour was a straightforward matter. In 2015, we wish to see all new cars sold in Europe fitted with this device. It will activate automatically in case of accident, even if the driver is unconscious. It could also be activated manually This device could prove to be very valuable, especially in rural areas. According to the figures, 2 500 lives could be saved each year. The French group PSA has already jumped on the bandwagon.

 
  
 		 

  Nuno Teixeira (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The eCall system seeks to improve assistance in the event of an accident, as it triggers an automatic call to the respective emergency services, with information about the time of the accident and the exact location, description and driving direction of the vehicle involved. eCall can therefore reduce the number of fatalities and the severity of injuries. This service, which has already been introduced by the Commission on a voluntary basis, will now be made obligatory for all vehicles from 2015. The Member States are therefore called on to define which infrastructure will receive the emergency calls, and mobile network operators are called on to incorporate this system into their networks, so that the calls will be a free public service using the 112 number. Moreover, it must be interoperable with existing private systems and data sharing must be restricted to what is necessary for this specific purpose. I support this report because I believe it benefits the European public, and also because it opens up new opportunities for the motor vehicle industry, as it can be used for new applications and services.

 
  
 		 

  Silvia-Adriana Ţicău (S&D), in writing. – (RO) I voted for the report on eCall: a new 112 service for citizens, because it is estimated that the full integration of the system in cars in the EU will save roughly 2 500 lives annually. The aim of the in-vehicle eCall system is to ensure the automatic notification of the emergency services in the case of a serious accident, with the purpose of reducing road fatalities and alleviating the severity of road accident injuries through the faster arrival of qualified and equipped assistance. The emergency call is generated automatically via the activation of in-vehicle sensors which, when activated, establish a voice and data connection directly with the public safety answering points. We should highlight agricultural and industrial vehicles, particularly agricultural tractors, which operate in remote and isolated areas, and are therefore often unable to notify the emergency services in the event of an accident. I voted for the paragraph which calls on the Commission to consider whether the eCall system needs to be extended in the near future to include other vehicles, such as heavy goods vehicles, buses, coaches and powered two-wheelers, and to assess whether it also needs to be introduced for agricultural tractors and industrial vehicles.

 
  
 		 

  Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE), in writing. – It is said that with the eCall system, 2 500 lives will be saved annually in the EU and severe injuries will be reduced by 10-15%. With this service, we can avoid the suffering of 2 500 families every year.

Although I note that there are several doubts about eCall, such as coordination, data protection, public and private added value services, possible false alarms generated by eCalls, etc., I can only see the positive points of it, namely, that it ensures automatic notification, faster arrival of emergency teams and that the call is made without encountering any language barrier in any EU country.

I will support this report because any measure taken that helps to save lives is a very positive action.

 
  
 		 

  Derek Vaughan (S&D), in writing. – I support calls for a free-of-charge emergency eCall system, which would alert rescue services to road crashes automatically. Such a system could help save lives and reduce injuries following serious road accidents. An in-vehicle eCall system would automatically alert emergency services to the location of accidents, which will enable victims to be treated by professionals as quickly and efficiently as possible. I believe that this system should be made available to all motorists across the EU. If introduced, we could see 2 500 fewer deaths a year and the severity of injuries would also be reduced. I now hope that the Commission will respond to calls from MEPs and come forward with some binding legislation on this issue.

 
  
 		 

  Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (FR) Road accidents are still one of the major causes of death and injury, not only in the European Union but throughout the world, and this at a time when technological developments are able to guarantee leading-edge, quality services in the fields of road safety and immediate intervention. This is the case with eCall, a system that sends emergency calls to answering point operators which will allow rapid assistance in case of accidents and which is closely linked with 112, the European emergency number.

I welcome the attention the text pays to the free and universally accessible nature of the eCall system as a public service, whilst taking into account the various categories of vehicles and the needs of drivers, including disabled drivers, as well as the importance it attaches to data protection and the privacy of the beneficiaries, with their prior agreement.

 
  
 		 

  Oldřich Vlasák (ECR), in writing. – (CS) I abstained from the report, although my own country is one of the pioneers of this solution. Although reducing road accidents and saving lives is a priority for me, it is obvious that nothing comes for free in this world, and somebody always has to pick up the bill. The proposal in Articles 9 and 39 for eCall to be free of charge is therefore problematic, as it suggests that, in the case of new vehicles, calls would be payment-free – where there is no problem because they are free already – and so would the equipment. In view of the fact that someone will have to pay for it, we will see either a further assault on public finances or higher prices for vehicles, if the burden is transferred to car makers, who will pass it on. The issue of possible costs for the emergency services from false alarms is also rather problematic, a fact pointed out by the rapporteurs themselves. I therefore support the eCall service, but I would like a clear statement on who will pay and from what source.

 
  
 		 

  Dominique Vlasto (PPE), in writing. – (FR) Parliament has just laid the bases for the deployment of eCall, an innovative system that is able automatically to alert the emergency services within the EU in the event of a car accident. I wish to see technology neutrality. This is a prerequisite for an effective system capable of supporting innovation. Whilst some manufacturers have already adopted comparable systems, I see no value in our making them incompatible with eCall. Let us avoid a war amongst the lobbies to impose a system when so many lives are at stake. If eCall must be technology neutral, it must also be financially neutral. This innovation cannot be achieved to the detriment of the consumer. The system aims to be general and obligatory. In these circumstances, we cannot impose an unreasonable cost on future buyers. I also think it is essential to introduce the conditions for free and fair competition to avoid the appearance of unfair charges. I therefore supported this recommendation in order to introduce this innovative system in the best manner possible. The era of free movement has become a reality in Europe; safety must not stop at the borders. Europe must continue to be a leader in road safety matters.

 
  
 		 

  Angelika Werthmann (NI), in writing. – The Commission decided in 2011 to adopt some legislative measures to introduce a binding eCall system, so it will be necessary to bring in a new regulation to ensure that all vehicles will be equipped with the right components to make an eCall possible. Today, Parliament is voting on a motion for a resolution which reflects its points of view and main guidelines to the Commission.

 
  
 		 

  Janusz Władysław Zemke (S&D), in writing. – (PL) Better implementation of the eCall service across the European Union will improve road safety. Motor vehicles would be installed with a system which sends an alarm signal to the emergency services automatically, something which is extremely important when the victims of an accident have lost consciousness. If qualified and well-equipped assistance were able to reach accidents more quickly, we would be able to bring down Europe’s high number of accident fatalities.

In my opinion, however, something which must worry us is the lack of progress on voluntary implementation of this service in some Member States, just as we are seeing delays in the efficient functioning of the European emergency number 112, on which the eCall project we are talking about is to be based. It is imperative that the Commission, Parliament and the Council take action which will lead to the establishment of a public service of this kind throughout the EU, but on the understanding that it should be operational, affordable and accessible to all vehicle users.

It is also essential to adopt legislative measures to ensure that the establishment of an EU-wide eCall system will not, under any circumstances, infringe the civil rights of vehicle users, by being able to trace vehicle movements for example, or violate the guarantee to protect their personal data.

 
  
  

Report: Rodi Kratsa-Tsagaropoulou (A7-0190/2012)

 
  
 		 

  Luís Paulo Alves (S&D), in writing. – (PT) Making investment in Europe more attractive requires the implementation of measures and reforms at both European and national level. To make investing and working in Europe more attractive, it is crucial to create a level playing field for companies. Developing the internal market has to be one of the EU’s main priorities for developing a favourable climate that encourages companies and consumers. This is particularly important in a globalised economy, where businesses have some flexibility in choosing where to operate. The regulatory environment needs to be further improved, to enable businesses in Europe to enhance their competitiveness and their ability to grow and create jobs.

 
  
 		 

  Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE), in writing. – I voted in favour of this important resolution on attractiveness of investing in Europe, which was adopted at a very crucial time for Europe, during which attracting investments and ensuring a balanced investment base in European regions are necessary elements for growth and economic recovery. We, Members of the European Parliament, urgently ask for growth to create wealth and employment, to encourage the competitiveness of the Union globally, and to increase economic and regional convergence within the EU. I support the position of the rapporteur that our goal needs to be dual: firstly, Europe needs to remain the first investment destination at a global level – a position that is at stake given the strong global competition from new investment destinations; secondly, investments need to contribute to balanced growth and cohesion within the EU. We, Members of the European Parliament, call for a European, comprehensive and integrated strategy for investments, within the framework of the EU 2020 strategy, to enhance the EU’s effort to achieve higher growth rates and create jobs, particularly in countries that face weak growth or recession, as is the case in Greece.

 
  
 		 

  Elena Oana Antonescu (PPE), in writing. – (RO) At a time when the economic and financial crisis has had a direct impact on the standard of living of many European citizens, reinforcing the European Union’s position as a main global destination for foreign investment is vital for European countries’ economic recovery. It is imperative to adopt measures to help both make Europe’s workers and companies more competitive and make Member States’ economies more attractive to foreign investors.

Adopting these policies is the only solution for creating jobs and kick-starting economic growth. At international level, it is important for the European Union to retain its role in promoting and actively participating in the processes supporting global economic governance. I endorse and encourage the European Union’s policy of continuing its efforts to sign bilateral or multilateral agreements promoting free trade and the EU’s involvement in these trade arrangements.

 
  
 		 

  Sophie Auconie (PPE), in writing. – (FR) Another topic in this plenary sitting shows that the strategy for growth, jobs and the competitiveness of our companies is under way. It has not waited for the French socialists. I voted in favour of a text whose objective is to attract foreign investors to Europe. Even though Europe remains the main destination region for foreign direct investment, weak economic growth, high taxation and high public debt accumulation raise concerns to investors. We must ensure that businesses can compete openly and fairly, promote the entrepreneurial spirit amongst local entrepreneurs and fully exploit the Structural Funds. The growing difficulties faced by SMEs in accessing funding show us that there is a need to encourage investment in the real economy. As Parliament’s rapporteur on the motion for a resolution on the Social Business Initiative – creating a favourable climate for social enterprises, key stakeholders in the social economy and innovation, it is this form of support that I wish to provide to social enterprises. I also welcome the political agreement that was reached on my report last week, an agreement that was arrived at thanks especially to the constructive proposals put forward by the Commission and by Michel Barnier’s office.

 
  
 		 

  Liam Aylward and Pat the Cope Gallagher (ALDE), in writing. – (GA) We fully endorse the report’s recommendations to the EU to address the Union’s weaknesses and strengthen its advantages, in order to attract and maximise global investment opportunities.

We fully support what it says about increasing the benefits of the cohesion policy, addressing human capital needs in the EU, and encouraging research and innovation. Our competitive corporate tax rate, however, is the cornerstone of Ireland’s attractiveness for foreign direct investment and global businesses.

Harmonisation of the corporate tax rate (CCCTB) would very adversely affect that strong element of the Irish economy which is essential for economic recovery and growth.

Taxation matters are a national competence and EU institutions must respect that. Under the additional protocol in relation to the concerns of the Irish people on the Treaty of Lisbon, which was recently ratified in the European Parliament, taxation matters are a competence of Member States.

In our opinion, the CCCTB would not improve the functioning of the single market but would adversely interfere with small open economies such as Ireland’s. For that reason, we abstained on this report.

 
  
 		 

  Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D), in writing. – (LT) I voted in favour of this report on reviewing the strategy for investment in Europe and supplementing it with new instruments. I believe that it is essential to exploit the EU’s advantage as the world’s largest single common market (including its high standard of living, high labour productivity, legal certainty and research and innovation capacity). I agree that as the level of unemployment increases and forecasts for Europe’s recovery remain pessimistic, new measures need to be taken to retain current investors and attract new ones. In order to tackle the challenges of the recession and slow economic growth, there is a need for more efficient tools and methods, new funding mechanisms and investment schemes. I agree that increasing investment in Europe, creating jobs within the EU and maintaining the EU’s international competitiveness must be a priority. It is important to achieve smart, sustainable and inclusive growth in the EU by reducing regional disparities.

 
  
 		 

  Regina Bastos (PPE), in writing. – (PT) In a situation of incipient economic growth, market instability and increased global imbalances, the EU needs to strengthen its competitive advantages in order to attract investment, and thus promote balanced growth and greater cohesion. This report, for which I voted, calls on the Commission to draft a communication assessing and promoting the attractiveness of investing in Europe. This should include recommendations to the Member States and act as one of the bases for enhancing the EU investment environment. Despite being the world’s largest recipient of foreign direct investment, Europe needs to fix its weaknesses and make the most of its advantages and strengths, given increased competition from developing countries. Weak economic growth in Europe, high taxes and excessive public debt are factors which raise concerns among investors. However, the high quality and diversity of our human capital, the predictability of the business environment, and the high potential for research and innovation all work to our market’s advantage and are factors that should be strengthened and enhanced.

 
  
 		 

  Sergio Berlato (PPE), in writing. – (IT) Europe is considered to be the largest regional destination for foreign direct investment. A quarter of the world’s total consumption and investment takes place within its borders. However, the weak economic growth Europe has recorded in these last years and the high public debt accumulation in Member States raise concerns to investors, which have been magnified in the face of global competition, especially from the emerging economies. There are two distinct aspects to consider when it comes to the attractiveness of investing in Europe – on the one hand, there is the need to make Europe an attractive destination for foreign investors and, on the other, the need to make entrepreneurship attractive for the local entrepreneur. Reforms are needed to attract investment to Europe, at both national and European levels, aimed at improving the functioning of the single European market. I therefore agree with the rapporteur’s request to the Commission to draw up a communication to evaluate as well as promote the attractiveness of investing in Europe, including policy recommendations to Member States targeted at enhancing the investment environment in the Union. In my opinion, furthermore, we need to improve the regulatory framework further so as to enable small and medium-sized enterprises to compete fairly, so that we can make Europe an attractive place in which to invest and work and enhance its ability to create wealth and jobs.

 
  
 		 

  Mara Bizzotto (EFD), in writing. – (IT) I am voting in favour of the Kratsa-Tsagaropoulou report on the attractiveness of investing in Europe. This report is intended to encourage changes in existing legislation in order to promote public and private investment, whether from within Europe or from third countries, for which the incentive is currently lacking, especially on account of the excessive tax burden. The aim is to establish a common policy directed at monetary, trade and budgetary stability, and to increase investment, notably in renewable energy, and, above all, in support of small and medium-sized enterprises, which represent the beating heart of European industry, especially Italian industry.

 
  
 		 

  Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D), in writing. – (LT) I voted in favour of this report because the economic, financial and fiscal crisis in the European Union has significantly broadened economic and social disparities among Member States and regions, resulting in an uneven distribution of inward and outward investment across the European Union. The global economy has embarked on the road to recovery, but there is limited room for manoeuvre, and ensuring a steady economic recovery process requires policies at international, EU and national level to be cautious. The European Union suffers from weak growth and expected growth rates differ significantly across the European Union. This weak growth is due to continued uncertainty and a lack of consumer and market confidence. The financing of the Member States’ public debt has the effect of absorbing resources for investment, growth and employment, while capital flight from certain Member States to certain other Member States, as well as to certain third countries, may contribute to a worsening of the EU balance of payments situation. In order to tackle the fiscal crisis and enhance growth and employment, the Union should further exploit its strengths, such as the high level of consumption, education and quality of life, its research and innovation capacity, high labour efficiency and productivity, as well as a friendly and motivational business environment. It is therefore necessary to establish a consistent framework of stability within monetary, fiscal and trade policy, in order to facilitate the flow of direct investment in all Member States and EU regions, thereby contributing to correcting the European Union’s macro-economic imbalances.

 
  
 		 

  Philippe Boulland (PPE), in writing. – (FR) I voted in favour of the report on the attractiveness of investing in Europe. This report sets the European Union two objectives for reviving investment: making Europe an attractive destination again for foreign investors and promoting the entrepreneurial spirit amongst local entrepreneurs. These measures must allow us to counterbalance weak economic growth, high taxation and high public debt accumulation, which are raising major concerns to investors. I also support the recommendations the rapporteur makes in this document relating to the fields upon which we need to focus our energy and our action: we must address human capital needs better, ensure stability and improve access to finance, strengthen territorial cooperation, enhance the single market and boost research and innovation.

 
  
 		 

  Alain Cadec (PPE), in writing. – (FR) I voted in favour of the report on the attractiveness of investing in Europe. This report especially underlines the need for stressing the attractiveness of the Structural Funds and of the single market to attract investors. I share the rapporteur’s vision of an integrated investment strategy within the framework of the Europe 2020 strategy. It is a good thing to reinforce coordination in this area, given the difficult economic context confronting us in Europe. Our ability to remain attractive and competitive in an increasingly competitive world is at stake.

 
  
 		 

  Maria Da Graça Carvalho (PPE), in writing. – (PT) Making investment in Europe more attractive requires the implementation of measures and reforms at both European and national level. To make investing and working in Europe more attractive, it is vital to create conditions whereby companies can enjoy a climate of fair and open competition. The internal market is one of the EU’s main priorities for developing a favourable climate that encourages companies and consumers. It is vital to promote the two ways of attracting investment: a) making Europe an attractive destination for foreign investors; and b) making the business environment attractive for local entrepreneurs. I therefore voted for this report, as I believe, inter alia, that it is essential to develop the EU’s human capital by modernising labour markets and the education systems of the Member States, and by promoting the mobility of students, researchers, professors and workers.

 
  
 		 

  David Casa (PPE), in writing. – In order to recover from the economic crisis and stimulate growth in the region, Europe needs to make itself more attractive for foreign direct investment. This can be achieved partially through fostering entrepreneurship, which requires reforming the regulatory environment to increase the competitiveness of European businesses and their ability to create jobs. I believe that the suggestions outlined in this report are compatible with such needs in terms of future investment and have therefore voted in favour of the resolution.

 
  
 		 

  Carlos Coelho (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The effects of the economic and financial crisis which has been plaguing the EU have contributed significantly to increasing economic and social disparities between Member States and regions, including a huge imbalance in the distribution of investment. Until recently, this area was dependent on bilateral treaties, with a large number of agreements, causing massive fragmentation and contributing to a lack of uniformity in the treatment of investors in the EU, and in their level of growth. As the Treaty of Lisbon has granted the EU exclusive competence in the field of foreign direct investment, it will be responsible for setting out an international investment policy that increases competitiveness and contributes to achieving the objectives set out in the Europe 2020 strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth.

A comprehensive common policy on investment should be developed that can provide investors with greater legal certainty and a predictable and stable framework that is fair and properly regulated. It is important to make Europe a more attractive space for investing and working, creating the necessary conditions for businesses to enjoy a climate of open competition. This will have a significant effect in terms of increasing productivity, with a positive impact on growth and employment.

 
  
 		 

  Emer Costello (S&D), in writing. – I voted in favour of the report on the attractiveness of investing in Europe, which calls on the Commission to present a strategy on how to make investment, in particular, foreign direct investment, in Europe more attractive. I welcome the concern expressed about high youth unemployment figures and the measures proposed throughout the report to address this. In particular, the support for a youth guarantee scheme, which would ensure that every young person in Europe is offered a job, further education or work-focused training at the latest four months after leaving education or after becoming unemployed, is an important initiative to tackle youth unemployment. The calls for an increase in funding for mobility and development of knowledge, through the ‘Erasmus for All’ programme, are also welcomed as a tool towards both future investment and a reduction of youth unemployment.

 
  
 		 

  Corina Creţu (S&D), in writing. – (RO) I voted for the resolution on increasing the attractiveness for investments. The EU needs to respond appropriately to the challenges of stabilising the international economy in order to fully exploit the global opportunities available. The EU has to address its weaknesses and enhance the advantages of all countries and regions to attract local and international investments which will contribute to its balanced growth and cohesion. The EU is the world’s largest trading bloc and external trade has so far played a dynamic role in boosting growth, especially in the services sector. At the same time, attracting investment needs to be distinguished at two levels: making Europe an attractive destination for foreign investors and making entrepreneurship attractive for local entrepreneurs. Reforms, both at national and European level, are necessary to improve the functioning of the single market and fully exploit the Structural Funds.

 
  
 		 

  Rachida Dati (PPE) , in writing. – (FR) Europe has many instruments at its disposal to return to growth, boost market confidence and attract investments. It is high time for the Union to make full use of them. That is what this report reminds us of, and that is why I voted in its favour. I especially welcome the emphasis it lays on the development of the ‘Erasmus for Enterprises’, ‘Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs’ programmes and the ‘COSME’ competitiveness programme for SMEs. Europe has enormous opportunities to promote exchanges and intercultural dialogue amongst entrepreneurs, especially amongst the younger ones. These opportunities must be taken.

 
  
 		 

  Christine De Veyrac (PPE), in writing. – (FR) I voted in favour of this text, which encourages the national governments to make the reforms necessary to improve the business climate in the EU in order to attract foreign investment to our regions. The Member States have to make efforts to reassure investors, by controlling their budgets, by reforming corporate taxation and by improving access to credit and European aid for SMEs. As for European Union public funds, these must now be used, as a priority, for major projects that are essential to reviving our regions. The pursuit of and increase in investment must be a priority for all, for a rapid return to strong growth in the single market.

 
  
 		 

  Edite Estrela (S&D), in writing. – (PT) I voted for the report on ‘the attractiveness of investing in Europe’, as it calls on the Commission to put forward a strategy to make foreign direct investment in Europe more attractive, in particular, by investing in cohesion policy, creating jobs for more young people, combating tax evasion, and facilitating the mobility of citizens and workers.

 
  
 		 

  José Manuel Fernandes (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The economic and financial crisis that Europe is experiencing, with restrictive public investment policies due to economic governance, has led to the bankruptcy of many companies and a sharp increase in unemployment, with the threat of social collapse. Despite the crisis, the EU continues to be the world’s main beneficiary of investment. However, some companies are relocating their factories to countries with lower taxes, less bureaucracy and cheaper labour. It is therefore urgent to reverse this situation by reducing bureaucracy and cutting taxes for our entrepreneurs, in order to prevent the commercial centre of the world from moving from Europe to the Pacific. It is also vital to make our companies more competitive by investing in innovation and technological development. I therefore welcome the presentation of this report on the attractiveness of investing in Europe, for which I voted. I also hope that it will contribute towards strengthening economic growth in the EU, as this is a region that values the security and quality of capital, has highly qualified professionals, has an excellent transport network, is committed to innovation and technological development, and ensures monetary and financial stability.

 
  
 		 

  João Ferreira (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (PT) This report focuses on what it considers to be the need to develop the internal market, in order to develop ‘a friendly and motivational environment for businesses and consumers’ which is able to attract both national and international investment. In order for this investment to take place, the rapporteur argues that ‘the EU needs a coherent political, economic and regulatory framework’. The elements that make up this framework include promoting the establishment of new trade agreements with third countries; structural reforms in the Member States in order to ensure greater coordination between the policies of the EU; the modernisation of labour markets, through flexicurity; education and professional training to meet the needs of the single market; economic governance; and the Euro Plus Pact. In other words, it is an example of the savage neoliberal agenda that has driven the process of dismantling society’s progress that is under way in the EU, and the unprecedented aggression being inflicted on workers and the public. Naturally, we voted against.

 
  
 		 

  Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D), in writing. – (SK) Instability in international financial markets is currently high. The huge debt levels and rising oil prices pose significant risks for the future. It is necessary and important to seek solutions to reduce these risks of negative development. Structural problems, insufficient global rebalancing, a persistent development gap, rising unemployment – these are all current problems to which we must respond appropriately and which we must urgently resolve in the spirit of cooperation and social solidarity.

Europe remains the largest regional destination for foreign direct investment (FDI). A quarter of the world’s total consumption and investment takes place within its expanding borders. Investors are attracted to the EU market mainly as a result of its high-quality and diverse human capital, its emphasis on corporate social responsibility, its relatively predictable business environment and its high potential in research and innovation. Despite these facts, we do not make full use of the EU’s potential, and high taxes disincentivise investors, as does the huge public debt. Meanwhile, global competition from emerging economies is growing steadily. In this context, the single internal EU market is of particular importance. This is one of our most important priorities. With its 500 million consumers, it offers tremendous advantages for investors; we must therefore continue to develop and support those regimes that facilitate and encourage investment in the EU. I am firmly convinced that especially during this crisis, we must promote our strengths more than ever before.

 
  
 		 

  Françoise Grossetête (PPE), in writing. – (FR) I voted in favour of this report because, whatever the cost, if we wish to come out of the current economic crisis unscathed, we must succeed in attracting worldwide investors to the European Union. Europe remains the main destination region for foreign direct investment (FDI), but its share is falling. Weak economic growth, high taxation and debt raise concerns on the part of investors which can be magnified in the face of global competition, especially from emerging economies. The EU must address its weaknesses and exploit its competitive advantages. We must make Europe an attractive destination once more for foreign investors and promote entrepreneurial spirit amongst local entrepreneurs. To do so, the EU needs a coherent political, economic and regulatory framework based on sustainable growth objectives and the Community method. We must, for example, address human capital needs better (by focusing on education and training), ensure stability and improve access to finance (especially for SMEs), promote the use of public-private partnerships, boost research and innovation and enhance the single market. We need a coherent, realistic economic and business policy.

 
  
 		 

  Juozas Imbrasas (EFD), in writing. – (LT) I voted in favour of this resolution on the attractiveness of investing in Europe because the economic, financial and fiscal crisis in the EU has significantly broadened economic and social disparities among Member States and regions, resulting in an uneven distribution of inward and outward investment across the EU. It is necessary to establish a consistent framework of stability within monetary, fiscal and trade policy in order to facilitate the flow of direct investment in all Member States and EU regions, thereby contributing to correcting the EU’s macro-economic imbalances. Today, we really need to mobilise EU policies to fully support growth, step up efforts to finance the economy through investment and strengthen job creation. Investors are attracted to the EU market mainly as a result of its high-quality and diverse human capital, its emphasis on corporate social responsibility, its relatively predictable business environment and its high potential in research and innovation. Nevertheless, Europe’s weak economic growth, high taxation and high public debt accumulation raise concerns on the part of investors which can be magnified in the face of global competition, especially from emerging economies, as well as the lack of opportunities to exploit the EU’s full potential. The Commission is therefore asked to prepare a communication to evaluate as well as promote the attractiveness of investing in Europe, including policy recommendations to Member States targeted at enhancing the EU investment environment. There is concern about the high youth unemployment figures in a number of Member States and negative employment prospects, particularly in Lithuania.

 
  
 		 

  Philippe Juvin (PPE), in writing. – (FR) The attractiveness of investing in the European Union is essential to the strategy for economic growth. The EU must retain its place as the top destination worldwide for foreign investment. It must, therefore, make investment a central component of all the flagship initiatives implemented within the framework of the Europe 2020 strategy. To this end, Parliament is inviting the Commission to step up coordination of Member States’ economic, tax and social policies with a view to attracting foreign investment. The report also recommends making full and effective use of innovative investment measures. I voted in favour of this report in the July part-session.

 
  
 		 

  Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE), in writing. – (PL) Ensuring that investing in Europe is competitive should be a priority for the European institutions, particularly in view of the current crisis. Increasing the level of investment and, in particular, of foreign direct investment, would stimulate the economies of the Member States and reduce the negative effects of fiscal consolidation. Therefore, I support initiatives involving continued funding of cohesion policy, because cohesion policy increases competitiveness and attracts investment to less-developed regions.

Facilitating the access of small and medium-sized enterprises to finance is a key factor in increasing investment. This not only involves fighting the credit crunch, but also ensuring alternative ways for SMEs to raise capital, such as by accessing European venture capital funds. However, regulation of such funds should aim to impose requirements which would reduce investment risk.

Stimulating research and innovation is also extremely important for the growth of investment in this area in the EU, as it has particular potential, mainly because of its qualified workforce. However, the introduction of a single EU patent, although a good idea, may also have negative consequences. Introducing this kind of single patent would mean a dramatic rise in the number of patents in all Member States, which could place significant restrictions on enterprises and, as a result, reduce investment. For this reason, I think further debate is needed on this matter.

 
  
 		 

  Sergej Kozlík (ALDE), in writing. – (SK) At present, Europe needs to respond adequately to the challenges of stabilising the international economy. The EU is the world’s largest trading bloc and Europe remains the largest regional destination for foreign direct investment (FDI). EU flows are dominated by the US which, in 2008, accounted for more than one third of the EU’s outward FDI. It was 25 times as high as the corresponding figure for China. Switzerland and Canada also accounted for a significant share of EU FDI flows. Attracting investment in Europe requires measures and reforms, both at European and national level. Together with the US, the EU financial markets continue to provide around three quarters of global financial services. The EP welcomes the measures in this area, as well as the proposal to establish a European venture capital fund. I support Parliament’s position on improving the attractiveness of investing in Europe.

 
  
 		 

  Giovanni La Via (PPE), in writing. – (IT) The European Union is the most important area from the point of view of the economic and productive sector. Nevertheless, partly as a result of the crisis, our region has latterly lost the attractive features that had made it a leading player. Making investment in Europe more attractive will require political action on several fronts. We must improve the way the single market works, make maximum use of the opportunities afforded to us by cohesion policy, and take full advantage of the new means represented by project bonds. Political determination on all fronts, starting with effective communication and using tourism as a lever by promoting our rich cultural heritage, unique in the world, is the road we must stick to faithfully in order to play an active part in the process of reform that we need to exit from the crisis, by promoting the ‘made in Europe’ and ‘made in Italy’ brands.

 
  
 		 

  Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE), in writing. – (PL) Despite continually rising youth unemployment, no measures are in evidence which might change the situation. There is a lack of special programmes to help young people, and not just at European level, because specific and effective measures are also lacking at national level. Europe faces the problem of an ageing society and, in a few years’ time, this is going to be a serious social and economic problem. The low level of economic growth and the high costs of labour are discouraging investment in this part of Europe. I think we need to react quickly to these worrying signs. We need to make the European market more attractive, because the regions have a great deal of untapped potential which is often not even noticed.

Cohesion policy should be the key to solving macro-economic and regional problems, leading to higher competitiveness and economic growth in the regions and the creation of much-needed new jobs, in particular, for young people. I think the Kratsa-Tsagaropoulou report on the attractiveness of investing in Europe is a good one, so I voted in favour of its adoption.

 
  
 		 

  Ramona Nicole Mănescu (ALDE), in writing. – (RO) I voted for the report on the attractiveness of investing in Europe because it plays a key role in boosting competitiveness, productivity and the potential for economic growth. We need as much investment as possible, both in infrastructure and innovation, and in scientific and social initiatives.

The EU’s cohesion policy makes a significant contribution to the European economy and is one of the largest EU sources of investment. The Commission and Member States need to table specific measures for supporting all the companies offering jobs under the Europe 2020 strategy and in line with national and regional development strategies, and to ensure that funding decisions are based on the quality of the project and on its value to the strategies at national, regional, local and EU level.

I would also like to stress that a discriminatory approach towards large companies could hamper innovation and reduce the competitiveness of other EU companies – by this I mean SMEs in particular – by excluding the latter from vital global partnerships in collaborative innovation and by reducing their access to state of the art technology.

 
  
 		 

  David Martin (S&D), in writing. – I voted for this report, which welcomes the ECB’s longer-term refinancing operations (LTRO); calls on the ECB to further act in a decisive way in addressing the current euro area debt crisis by maintaining price stability while, at the same time, minimising negative spill-over effects on the real economy and the investments that the banking sector’s liquidity problems might generate; believes that the banking sector must take the necessary steps to address its structural weaknesses with regard to longer-term liquidity risks in order to restore investor confidence and therefore to avoid the need for the ECB to intervene so massively in future; considers that the bank’s operational framework should be shaped in such a way that a proportion of the grants would be made available for development purposes and to support small and medium-sized enterprises.

 
  
 		 

  Clemente Mastella (PPE), in writing. – (IT) Europe needs to respond adequately to the challenges of stabilising the international economy in order to exploit global opportunities to the maximum. We must address our weaknesses and strengthen the advantages of all countries and regions to attract local and international investment that will contribute to our balanced growth and our cohesion. The Union is the world’s largest trading power and remains the largest regional destination for foreign direct investment. Nevertheless, we must be capable of exploiting our competitive advantages, given the rising competition from developing countries. This goal must be at the heart of the EU’s investment reforms and strategy, at both European and national levels. At the global level, the EU must continue its efforts to conclude bilateral and multilateral free trade agreements as well as participate actively in global economic governance. Attracting investment in Europe needs measures and reforms, at both European and national levels. Ensuring that businesses can compete openly and fairly is crucial with respect to making Europe an attractive place in which to invest and work. The single market is one of the most significant priorities in developing a friendly and motivational environment for businesses and consumers.

 
  
 		 

  Véronique Mathieu (PPE), in writing. – (FR) I voted in favour of this report on the attractiveness of investing in Europe as, whilst we may be able to congratulate ourselves on the fact that Europe represents the top destination worldwide in terms of foreign direct investment, we still need to take measures to maintain the conditions favourable to these investments. In fact, the debt crisis and the lack of national investments could worry foreign investors. The report proposes a series of recommendations, including an integrated investment strategy within the framework of the Europe 2020 strategy.

 
  
 		 

  Iosif Matula (PPE), in writing. – (RO) I voted for the report from Rodi Kratsa-Tsagaropoulou because I think that, during the current economic and financial crisis, it is vital for us to focus our attention on attracting the largest volume possible not only of foreign investment, but also of local investment in the European Union. I think that investment in training for workers, promoting the entrepreneurial spirit and encouraging a favourable environment for small entrepreneurs are key elements in terms of the EU’s ability to attract foreign direct investment.

I would like to highlight the need to ease the administrative burden faced by small and medium-sized enterprises as part of the process of accessing European funds. At the same time, developing and encouraging public-private investments and the effective use of structural instruments for promoting economic recovery are crucial to attracting and retaining foreign and domestic capital in the European Union. However, we cannot talk about attracting investment in Europe without considering the creation of a climate conducive to investment through sustained economic growth. Consequently, rules need to be applied guaranteeing both fair competition and a fair competitive environment.

 
  
 		 

  Mairead McGuinness (PPE), in writing. – This report contains references to the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB) and the simultaneous coordination of tax systems throughout Europe. I abstained on the final vote of this report, since taxation matters remain the competence of Member States.

 
  
 		 

  Alajos Mészáros (PPE), in writing. – (HU) Structural problems, rising unemployment and uncertainty continue to have a negative impact on our ability to deal with global growth challenges. In order for Europe to become more attractive to investors, these deficiencies need to be addressed, and measures and reforms need to be implemented both at European and at national level. Due to uncertainty, banks are experiencing financing difficulties, and resolute measures are therefore needed to enhance the financial markets. I agree that the European Union economy needs a financial sector that supports real economies, ensures stability, and is able to serve the needs of households and enterprises. SMEs are facing increasing difficulties in obtaining financing, and Member States should therefore implement regulatory measures that facilitate SME financing, seeing as how SMEs often act as drivers of local growth. The appropriate financing of cohesion policy is also important because it contributes to emphasising the benefits and innovation potential of regions and to highlighting their importance to growth, investment and employment. By promoting cultural industries, sport and tourism, which represent growing and attractive markets, we should also exploit the potential that lies in our historic heritage. I agree with the rapporteur, and therefore voted in favour of the report. Investments must be aimed at addressing the specific needs of the various regions and Member States while appropriately involving local communities.

 
  
 		 

  Louis Michel (ALDE), in writing. – (FR) The economic crisis that the European Union is experiencing, accompanied by low levels of growth and high levels of unemployment, has increased the economic, social and investment disparities between the Member States. The underdeveloped regions are benefiting from substantial European funding to attract potential investors and will continue to benefit from them. Solidarity, however, requires growth. The social acquis are the result of a high-performance economy. Social protection can only ever be the consequence of work and responsibility. We must make investment the central component of our European policies. We need an economic government that implements proactive policies to produce promising investments. We must complete the single market, the key driver of economic growth, by fully implementing the legislation on energy and services. We need the courage to restructure certain sectors. We must press for a more flexible mobilisation of the Structural Funds, promote the entrepreneurial spirit and provide access to funding. We have to resist the siren call of inward-looking economic protectionism which can only result in an illusory well-being. Whilst we need competitiveness, we also need solidarity.

 
  
 		 

  Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE), in writing. – (SK) The ongoing crisis highlights the urgent need to mobilise the Union’s policy to fully support growth and increase funding for the EU economy through investment. This, of course, is not achievable without the effective implementation of structural reforms in order to improve the business climate and create jobs in all regions of the EU. With its 500 million consumers, the European single market offers huge advantages for investors, and the EU therefore traditionally maintains a high potential to attract foreign direct investment. The European Union must know how to properly utilise the huge potential of the world’s largest single market when seeking a comprehensive solution for the debt crisis suffered by citizens and businesses. I believe, therefore, that in addition to making Europe an attractive destination for foreign investors, we must first create favourable business conditions for local entrepreneurs, who still face many obstacles in the internal market. Inward investment in the European Union should help not only to make the environment for foreign direct investment more attractive, but also help overall investment and business in the internal market by improving sustainable infrastructure for business, education, research and development. For these reasons, I support the report on the attractiveness of investing in Europe.

 
  
 		 

  Alexander Mirsky (S&D), in writing. – This report calls on the Commission to present a strategy on how to make investment, in particular, foreign direct investment, in Europe more attractive. I voted in favour because I call on the Commission to start working seriously.

 
  
 		 

  Andreas Mölzer (NI), in writing. – (DE) The economic crisis has left behind noticeable traces in Europe, even though we are gradually seeing signs that the situation is becoming more stable. Nevertheless, high levels of debt and rising oil prices represent a further risk. In addition, Europe still has to deal with the bankrupt states in the euro area, which have such poor credit ratings that investors there are few and far between. Furthermore, American rating agencies are making decisions about the creditworthiness of European countries, which can, in turn, lead to difficulties with investment and finance. As long as countries like Greece, Spain and Portugal are continuing to cause monetary instability in the euro area, it is likely to be difficult to prevent economic and social inequalities between the countries in the area, which is what the rapporteur is calling for. This is why I have abstained.

 
  
 		 

  Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE), in writing. – (FR) By voting in favour of this report, I am calling on the Commission to prepare a communication to evaluate and promote the attractiveness of investing in Europe. The economic, financial and budgetary crisis that the European Union is experiencing, high taxation and the economic and social disparities between the Member States and the regions are all factors that are putting a brake on foreign investment in Europe. This situation could deteriorate with growing competition from the emerging economies. The European Union needs to implement a strategy in order better to meet investor expectations.

 
  
 		 

  Rolandas Paksas (EFD), in writing. – (LT) I voted in favour of this resolution. In order to withstand competition from the emerging economies, we need to do our utmost to promote the attractiveness of investing in Europe. The Commission must therefore take immediate action and prepare a communication as a matter of urgency containing measures for enhancing the EU investment environment and recommendations to the Member States. Furthermore, it is very important to finally complete an effectively functioning internal market and modernise the European public procurement market.

 
  
 		 

  Maria do Céu Patrão Neves (PPE), in writing. – (PT) Weak economic growth in Europe, high taxation and excessive public debt are factors raising concerns among investors. However, the high quality and diversity of our human capital, the predictability of the business environment and the high potential in research and innovation all work to our market’s advantage and are factors that should be strengthened and enhanced. As I agree with this view, I am supporting the rapporteur’s request that the Commission draft a communication assessing and promoting the attractiveness of investing in Europe. This should include recommendations to the Member States and act as one of the bases for enhancing the EU investment environment. I voted for this report because of all of these facts.

 
  
 		 

  Aldo Patriciello (PPE), in writing. – (IT) The EU is the world’s largest trading bloc and external trade has so far played a dynamic role in boosting growth, especially in the services sector. A quarter of the world’s total consumption and investment takes place within its expanding borders, although it is a reduced share compared to the past. Nevertheless, Europe’s weak economic growth, high taxation and high public debt accumulation raise concerns on the part of investors, which can be magnified in the face of global competition, especially from emerging economies, as well as the lack of opportunities to exploit the EU’s full potential. The crisis is a global one and calls for an international response, and reforms at both national and European levels are necessary in order to improve the functioning of the single market and fully exploit the Structural Funds. With the aim of increasing the attractiveness of the European market and providing Europe with a coherent political, economic and regulatory framework, based on sustainable growth targets, I am voting in favour.

 
  
 		 

  Franck Proust (PPE), in writing. – (FR) The one advantage of the crisis is that it makes us ask ourselves relevant questions. This report has the answers. That is why I voted in favour of it. However, let us use our strengths and our words wisely: It is not enough to identify all of the options available to us to attract investment in Europe and thus revive our economy. We have to focus our efforts on the texts which will have the force of law in the coming years. I wish, of course, to talk about the guidelines of the Europe 2020 strategy and of how they translate at national level. I wish, particularly, to talk about Horizon 2020, the Framework Programme for Research and Innovation, the COSME programme for enterprises and SMEs and reform of the Structural Funds. However, not everything is decided within Europe. We must show pragmatism towards the outside world and require products arriving in our territory to comply with the same health and social standards as our own products. Otherwise, we have unfair competition. We must impose reciprocity in our trade. It is already there in the text of our agreements. Why is the Commission not doing anything?

 
  
 		 

  Paulo Rangel (PPE), in writing. – (PT) In a situation of incipient economic growth, market instability and increased global imbalances, the EU needs to strengthen its competitive advantages in order to attract investment to the region, and thus promote balanced growth and greater cohesion. This report, for which I voted, calls on the Commission to draft a communication assessing and promoting the attractiveness of investing in Europe. This should include recommendations to the Member States and act as one of the bases for enhancing the EU investment environment. Despite being the world’s number one recipient of foreign direct investment, Europe needs to fix its weaknesses and make the most of its advantages and strengths, given the increasing competition from developing countries. Weak economic growth in Europe, high taxation and high public debt consumption are factors which raise concerns among investors. However, the high quality and diversity of our human capital, the predictability of the business environment and the high potential in research and innovation all work to our market’s advantage, and are factors that should be strengthened and enhanced.

 
  
 		 

  Raül Romeva i Rueda (Verts/ALE), in writing. – In favour. This is a relatively uncontroversial own-initiative report calling on the Commission and the Member States to take action to make Europe more attractive to outside investors. Key points in the report are: (i) Maximising cohesion policy benefits through highlighting the regions’ comparative advantages and innovation opportunities and their importance for growth, investment and employment and promoting the use of EU funds as a catalyst for attracting additional financing from the EIB, EBRD, other international financial institutions and the private sector; (ii) Addressing human capital needs and potential through the promotion of high-quality education institutions and education and professional training and the mobility of students, researchers, professors and workers; (iii) Ensuring stability and improving access to finance through the EU taking a more active role and committing to a globally coordinated regulatory response and closer cross-border cooperation, making banks more robust and promoting equity financing to reduce dependence on banks, among others.

 
  
 		 

  Licia Ronzulli (PPE), in writing. – (IT) I voted in favour of this report as I believe that it identifies the most appropriate guidelines for a new common policy that will make Europe capable of attracting investment and capital from the rest of the world. In order to achieve this objective, we need structural reforms at both national and international levels and a new regulatory framework to enhance the competitiveness of businesses in Europe through growth and jobs, while addressing the macro-economic and social imbalances that still remain between different areas.

 
  
 		 

  Nikolaos Salavrakos (EFD), in writing. – Europe remains the largest regional destination for foreign direct investment (FDI).
