I voted in favour of this report as it proposes ideas and measures to promote the attractiveness of investing in Europe, including policy recommendations to Member States targeted at enhancing the EU investment environment.

 
  
 		 

  Edward Scicluna (S&D), in writing. – This report is particularly timely. With most European economies either stagnating or in recession, investment in the EU is badly needed. However, although there are many good proposals in this report, I and my delegation cannot support the proposal on harmonising the corporate tax base and we have therefore opted to abstain. Taxation policy remains a matter for Member States and, in any case, there are many more pressing priorities if we are to attract new investment. Most important is the need to complete the single market. More than twenty years after its creation, the single market – particularly in the services sector – is fragmented and differs from country to country. As a result of this, there are a number of Member States where it is very hard to start a business. Without a level playing field for businesses to operate in, we will continue to lose billions of euro of potential business activity. We need to make it easier for companies to do business in Europe and to make payments easier and faster, through closer cooperation in implementing rules on VAT and avoiding double taxation and by reducing the bureaucratic burden, particularly on small businesses. This will help to attract investment and drive our economic recovery.

 
  
 		 

  Sergio Paolo Francesco Silvestris (PPE), in writing. – (IT) High debt levels in developed markets and rising oil prices are key risks ahead. The international economic environment has continued to be characterised by an uneven performance, weak growth in advanced economies and a stronger, although slowing, expansion in emerging markets. Structural problems, insufficient global rebalancing, a persistent development gap, rising unemployment, high public and private debt and uncertainty continue to adversely affect global growth prospects. While volatility in international financial markets has subsided, it remains high and action is needed to further reduce downside risks. With this vote, we will try to encourage and attract investments in Europe and this requires measures and reforms at both European and national level. Ensuring that businesses can compete openly and honestly is crucial with respect to making Europe an attractive place to invest and work.

 
  
 		 

  Kay Swinburne (ECR), in writing. – The ECR Group has decided to abstain on this own-initiative report, despite many valuable points developed therein. We welcome the fact that the EU remains the largest regional destination for foreign direct investment (FDI), despite the slowdown in investment flows as a result of the lingering global crisis. Investors appreciate the investment opportunities of the EU single market, mainly due to its high-quality and diverse human capital, relatively predictable business environment and high potential in research and innovation. We concur with the rapporteur that more needs to be done to overcome the burden of high taxation and high public debt accumulation, which have resulted in a loss of EU competitiveness at global level such as to eliminate restrictions on the supply of venture capital funding in small and medium-sized enterprises. We also agree that promoting education, research and development and job creation in areas such as greenhouse gas emissions reduction, development of renewable energy sources and improvement of energy efficiency could contribute to attracting FDI in the EU. Nevertheless, we object to the outright call for the implementation of a directive on the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB) in the EU, as mentioned in paragraph 32 of the report.

 
  
 		 

  Nuno Teixeira (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The crisis affecting the EU and the world in general has highlighted the need for the EU to take a good look at itself in order to identify the challenges that it is facing and enhance the ways it benefits its main trading partners. Globalisation also requires that the different actors coordinate with one another on the various macro-economic and financial policies. This report lists several areas in which the EU and the Member States should increase their effectiveness and/or rethink their strategies. The rapporteur highlights a number of elements as essential to attracting direct investment to Europe: maximising the benefits of cohesion policy, in order to attract additional funding from innovative financial instruments, and suggesting strategies to develop human capital, such as modernising labour markets and education systems, underpinned by knowledge based on innovation and research. The report also reaffirms that the stability of the euro area and greater intervention in the financial system by the European Central Bank are necessary, as the credit crunch is adversely affecting the real economy. Lastly, I would like to highlight the importance of investment in transport infrastructure, energy and information and communication technology in order to increase Europe’s long-term competitiveness.

 
  
 		 

  Silvia-Adriana Ţicău (S&D), in writing. – (RO) I voted in favour of the resolution on the attractiveness of investing in Europe because the economic, financial and fiscal crisis in the EU has significantly widened the economic and social disparities among Member States and regions, resulting in an uneven distribution of inward and outward investment across the European Union. I support the objectives of the Innovation Union and I call on Member States to set themselves a goal of increasing investment in education, research and innovation, given the medium- and long-term positive effects these areas can have on growth and development. The EU should also promote the Trans-European Networks and worker, student and researcher mobility, and reinforce cooperation and complementary features between EU economies. I called on the Commission and Member States to implement the ‘European eGovernment Action Plan’, enabling them to provide eGovernment services more efficiently and at a lower cost, including to companies, at both local and cross-border level. I think that the EU and Member States should take action particularly to increase utilisation of the Structural Funds and the Cohesion Fund as a catalyst for attracting additional funding from the EIB, EBRD, other international financial institutions and the private sector, while encouraging initiatives based on public-private partnerships.

 
  
 		 

  Patrizia Toia (S&D), in writing. – (IT) I support this report because it is essential to attract new investors to the EU market. This is only possible through measures such as project bonds and far-reaching reforms such as the cohesion policy reform that we will adopt in 2013. Ambitious territorial development policies will allow the EU to maintain its high-quality human capital and foster an open and fair business environment as well as investment in research and innovation for successful products and business models, for the benefit of Europe’s economy and society.

The promotion of a strong industrial base needs to be put at the centre of reforms, particularly in those areas where the EU has traditionally been strong, as well as in high-tech sectors where a strong industrial base is essential to develop innovation in products, processes and services and to create new jobs. In a context of economic recovery, it is necessary to adopt ambitious legislation for SMEs by simplifying regulations and strengthening access to finance, promoting effective capital systems (venture and angel), and enhancing the role of private and public equity investments in financing long-term corporate growth. Parliament’s commitment will be maximal.

 
  
 		 

  Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE), in writing. – In the context of deep recession in some parts of Europe, it is important that in addition to the much needed structural reforms to make our economies more competitive, we take the time to think of how to attract more foreign investment into our continent.

Europe has to take advantage of its special historical and cultural characteristics and, at the same time, promote SMEs and allow regions to develop their own policies to attract investors. An approach based on one size fits all is doomed to fail.

 
  
 		 

  Derek Vaughan (S&D), in writing. – Investment in Europe and, in particular, foreign direct investment, is hugely important to Europe’s economy. This report, which I voted in favour of, calls on the Commission to present a strategy to make investment in Europe more attractive. Cohesion policy investment is vital to this, as is creating a more robust European industrial policy. I fully support the report’s call for the greater use of innovative financial instruments and its emphasis on the need to facilitate workers’ and citizens’ mobility, which is vital to ensuring further investment in jobs.

 
  
 		 

  Angelika Werthmann (NI), in writing. – The report discusses the position of the EU in the global economy as well as the consequences of this role, including challenges and duties. Certain goals like the development of infrastructure for companies, education and research, support for SMEs and the protection of employees are to be supported. Promotion of the European market’s attractiveness for international investors helps in the improvement of economic performance as well as the decline of unemployment rates.

 
  
 		 

  Jacek Włosowicz (EFD), in writing. – (PL) The most serious tax issues that Europeans face in cross-border situations are discrimination, double taxation and difficulties in claiming tax refunds and in obtaining information on foreign tax rules. I agree with the rapporteur, who believes that tax coordination should be an integral part of a growth strategy and that the Euro Plus Pact is correct in emphasising the importance of tax reforms.

Regarding corporate taxation, I, too, think that a Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base will contribute to addressing some serious fiscal obstacles to growth in the single market which create disincentives for investment in the EU. Therefore, any strategies for boosting the EU’s attractiveness to foreign investors should be based on an assessment of achievements and deficiencies related to completion of the internal market.

 
  
  

Report: Miloslav Ransdorf (A7-0183/2012)

 
  
 		 

  Charalampos Angourakis (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (EL) The report lays out the entire imperialist EU strategy east of the border with the Eastern partnership, through the trade links developed by the EU within that framework. The flagship proposal in the report is the establishment and development between the EU and every other country of a so-called ‘Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area’ (DCFTA) and ‘investment protection’, which really means the penetration of the euro-unifying monopolies throughout the Eastern partnership. It puts pressure on all the Eastern partners to join the WTO. It calls on the EU to step up efforts to enter into free trade agreements (FTAs), in a bid to neutralise Russian influence on these countries, thereby expressing the stiff competition between euro-unifying and Russian monopolies trying to gain a foothold on the emerging markets in the area. It openly proclaims that the EU must use these FTAs to intervene in these countries, including politically, on the pretext of democracy and human rights. It is especially insulting of Belarus, which it calls upon to join the WTO. It supports restrictive measures by the EU against that country and calls on the EU to step up aid to various NGOs and ‘civil society’, in the aim of imposing the political regime of its choice, so as to ‘eliminate obstacles to business’.

 
  
 		 

  Pino Arlacchi (S&D), in writing. – I voted for this report because it stresses that the conclusion and the implementation of the association agreements is a priority of the reviewed European Neighbourhood Policy regarding the Eastern partners. The creation of Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas (DCFTAs) is indeed one of the most ambitious tools of EU bilateral trade policy with the aim to achieve a stable economic environment which respects democracy and the rule of law. In addition, it is important to underline that prosperity and stability in the EU’s eastern neighbourhood are in the EU’s utmost interest and, moreover, I believe that stable relations between the EU and its Eastern partners will undoubtedly increase trade volumes in both directions.

 
  
 		 

  Sophie Auconie (PPE), in writing. – (FR) Six ex-USSR republics – Ukraine Belarus, Moldova, Armenia, Azerbaijan and Georgia – are associated with the European Union within the framework of the Eastern partnership. The main objective of this partnership is to support these countries in the pursuit of a democratic transition to avoid conflicts in the region, by opening up some areas of the single market. I supported the recommendations for each country, which differ in accordance with the democratic progress and respect for the principles of the rule of law in each. We have called for Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas whilst introducing the ‘more for more’ principle, a new concept which creates a link between political progress on the road to wide-ranging democratisation and economic liberalisation of trade.

 
  
 		 

  Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D), in writing. – (LT) I voted in favour of this report on the implementation of association agreements with the Eastern partnership’s trading partners in order to establish a Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area. As China’s impact on European trade is growing and Russia continues to engage in protectionist policies, the EU’s European Neighbourhood Policy with Eastern partners is one of the Union’s priority aims. I believe that the prospect of creating Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas (DCFTAs) with the EU is one of the greatest ambitions of EU bilateral trade policy for fighting tendencies towards protectionism at global level. The development of Eastern partnership trade is essential for avoiding regional conflicts in future, which lead to economic isolation. The development of trade relations with the Eastern partners is therefore important not just economically; its impact covers issues relating to the development of democracy, the rule of law and common EU principles. I believe that in the long term, the benefits of integration should compensate the Eastern partners for the efforts they have made.

 
  
 		 

  Mara Bizzotto (EFD), in writing. – (IT) I support Mr Ransdorf’s report on the Eastern partnership, which provides a framework for relations between the EU and Armenia, Georgia, Moldova, Ukraine, Azerbaijan and Belarus. Among them, the first four are already members of the World Trade Organisation whilst the last two are only observers. From the socio-political point of view, this area is still unstable, but the EU cannot avoid introducing partnership policies with it. This is, in fact, an area dominated by Russian influence and extremely rich in energy resources. Finally, it is likely that this type of EU policy will encourage these countries to carry out the much desired institutional reforms and modernisation.

 
  
 		 

  Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D), in writing.– (LT) I voted in favour of this report because the conclusion and implementation of association agreements including Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas (DCFTAs) is a priority aim and ambition of the reviewed European Neighbourhood Policy regarding the Eastern partners. Only four out of the six countries of the Eastern partnership are already members of the WTO, with the governments of Azerbaijan and Belarus having only observer status. However, all EU Eastern partners, being the ex-USSR states, share the same historical and institutional background. They have also faced similar challenges in their political and socio-economic transition over the past two decades. Furthermore, following the revolutionary events which took place in 2011 in the European Union’s Southern neighbourhood, EU interest has been focused on the southern neighbours and the countries belonging to the Eastern partnership and EU trade relations with them deserve the attention of the EU. Prosperity and stability in the EU’s eastern neighbourhood are in the EU’s utmost interest. As stable and predictable relations between the EU and its Eastern partners develop, trade volumes will undoubtedly increase in both directions. There needs to be an ambitious approach to integrating the economies of the EU and of the Eastern partnership countries through DCFTAs by including other aspects related to free and fair trade.

 
  
 		 

  Philippe Boulland (PPE), in writing. – (FR) I voted in favour of the report on the trade aspects of the Eastern partnership, which follows on from the joint communication from the European institutions on ‘a new response to a changing neighbourhood’. The Eastern partnership consists of the European Union, on the one hand and, on the other, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. As the EU is the main export market and the main source of imports for these countries, it was important to introduce new trade agreements suited to changing economic needs and capacities. Moreover, these agreements are in line with the idea of the ‘more for more’ principle. This concept creates a link between political progress on the road to wide-ranging democratisation and the economic liberalisation of trade. This report also stresses the need for regulatory convergence, with the aim of achieving gradual economic integration with the EU’s single market. This report, therefore, sends a strong political and economic signal to the countries in the Eastern partnership and stresses our commitment to them.

 
  
 		 

  Arkadiusz Tomasz Bratkowski (PPE), in writing. – (PL) I welcome the result of today’s vote on the report on the trade aspects of the Eastern partnership. During my many years in politics, I have had occasion to be involved in cross-border cooperation in Poland’s relations with Belarus and Ukraine. I have also been able to see the mutual benefits of this cooperation, and they are not just political and economic benefits, because they are also – if not primarily – social benefits.

Forging closer economic relations with Eastern partnership countries by creating free trade areas can, in the long term, facilitate effective implementation of EU foreign policy and help consolidate the European model of democracy and the economy.

However, building closer economic relations in a way which offers benefits to both sides should not be done without attaching conditions. Therefore, making specific recommendations to the EU’s neighbours referred to in the document will allow comprehensive aid programmes to be put in place and lasting relations to be built with credible partners who are conscious of our clearly defined expectations.

 
  
 		 

  Maria Da Graça Carvalho (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The creation of Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas with the EU is one of the main incentives for partner countries – namely Ukraine, Moldova, Georgia, Armenia and Azerbaijan – to pursue democratic reform, economic stabilisation and integration, transparency and trade regulation. These partnerships are a priority objective of the European Neighbourhood Policy with regard to its Eastern partners. I voted for the report, as I consider it vital to pursue the further deepening of the European Neighbourhood Policy in relation to our Eastern partners, namely, Ukraine, Moldova, Georgia, Armenia and Azerbaijan.

 
  
 		 

  Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE), in writing. – (FR) Today, the EU is the main trading partner of Ukraine, Belarus, Georgia, Armenia, Azerbaijan and Moldova. These countries must therefore transpose the standards required under the Eastern partnership neighbourhood instrument into their national legislations. However, we need to be aware that some of them, such as Belarus, under the yoke of an implacable dictatorship, or Ukraine, which is struggling to install a solid rule of law, are facing major political and economic difficulties. It is therefore up to the European Union to contribute to the introduction of a stable legal and economic environment in these countries.

 
  
 		 

  Christine De Veyrac (PPE), in writing. – (FR) I voted for this report, which supports the development of trade cooperation with our Eastern neighbours built on a win-win basis. The intensification of trade with these former Soviet countries will, in fact, allow us to secure our energy supplies whilst offering potential new openings to our companies. At the same time, these countries will be able to take advantage of our partnership to develop and diversify their economies and strengthen their democracy.

 
  
 		 

  Ioan Enciu (S&D), in writing. – I voted in favour of the motion for a European Parliament resolution on the trade aspects of the Eastern partnership because it highlights the importance of DCFTAs as a vital trade instrument for building up economic relationships with third countries.

It also contains a very important analysis of the ongoing trade, economic and social situation of the ongoing negotiations on the EU-Ukraine, EU-Moldova, EU-Georgia, EU-Armenia and EU-Azerbaijan association agreements.

I particularly welcome the underlined DCFTAs potential for conflict prevention through economic and social cohesion, which relies on the ‘more for more’ principle as the appropriate instrument for acknowledging the efforts of those who make the most progress and motivating others to step up their efforts.

The report expresses the need for the economic integration of the Eastern partners with the EU to be carried out according to the necessary political and social reforms, and that institution building and proper implementation of commitments are prerequisites for the successful implementation of DCFTAs.

 
  
 		 

  Edite Estrela (S&D), in writing. – (PT) I voted for the report on ‘trade aspects of the Eastern partnership’, as I consider the general and specific recommendations of each country to be positive in relation to the negotiation of deep and comprehensive agreements, the importance of technical assistance, the alignment of legislation, environmental standards and the involvement of civil society.

 
  
 		 

  Diogo Feio (PPE), in writing. – (PT) It is a cliché to say that trading partners do not go to war. Moreover, it is a cliché that does not even reflect the truth. Nonetheless, the truth is that conflicts between these sorts of partners tend to be fewer and the partners often aim to exhaust means of dialogue before resorting to war. Following years of tension on their eastern borders due to the Cold War and the Sovietisation of the region, it is reassuring to note that, despite the differences and disparities between the EU and its Eastern partners, there is a willingness today to prioritise trade issues and to seek an increasingly close relationship which is productive for all parties. It will not do to ignore the fact that there is still a long way to go, in particular, with regard to issues of democracy, human rights and combating corruption and violence, but it is right to acknowledge the work that has been done and some successes that have been achieved. I hope that this partnership will develop to the satisfaction of all parties, and that it will enable economic growth for all and closer relations between the different peoples and cultures, with respect for their respective identities.

 
  
 		 

  José Manuel Fernandes (PPE), in writing. – (PT) Mr Ransdorf’s report aims to promote and strengthen trade relations in the EU’s Eastern partnership. Over recent decades, the EU has favoured trade relations with eastern countries while encouraging democratisation and seeking to implement respect for fundamental human rights. This is an important partnership for these countries, but it is also vital for the EU in overcoming certain problems that the eastern Member States are facing. It is vital to resolve the problem of the pipeline with Moldova, open energy corridors and overcome visa-related issues with Ukraine. In relation to Georgia, although the President’s democratic ideals are well known, it is necessary to press ahead with the social reforms under way in order to end the scourge that is child labour. I welcome the establishment of this new Eastern partnership, with an agreement that covers not only trade in goods but also other areas such as increased solidarity and non-tariff barriers, as the EU should continue to support these peoples in order to ensure close integration which is always based on full respect for the rule of law and democracy.

 
  
 		 

  João Ferreira (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (PT) The majority in Parliament is going full steam ahead along a course that has been shown, in the reality of the EU as the largest free trade area in the world, to make no contribution towards resolving any of the problems that the workers and peoples are facing. The insistence on the free movement of goods and capital between the EU and these countries, and the ‘integration’ of the markets of the Eastern partnership countries advocated here, through the creation of ‘Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas’, only benefits the companies with a dominant position in production and marketing. The consequences of this are well known due to what has happened in Portugal: the destruction of small and medium-sized enterprises and national production, creating even more unemployment, and the destruction of workers’ rights. Moreover, as the situation of the EU demonstrates, ‘free trade’ has impacts that go far beyond purely trade issues, also influencing the state of democracy, and we believe that this is for the worse. ‘Free trade’ encourages the concentration and centralisation of the wealth of economically richer countries and their companies, and it runs counter to the development of fairer trade relations based on sovereignty, protection and increased national production, which can only be safeguarded by trade relations based on complementarity between countries.

 
  
 		 

  Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D), in writing. – (SK) Following the recent events, generally known as the Arab Spring, our attention has become focused on the European Union’s southern neighbours. However Eastern partnership countries and EU trade relations with these countries cannot be overlooked. Our eastern neighbours are the ex-USSR states. They share the same historical background and, over the past twenty years, they have been working towards a political and socio-democratic transition. Four out of the six countries of the EU’s Eastern partnership are already members of the World Trade Organisation (WTO), and the remaining two countries have observer status. The primary aim in this respect of the EU’s Neighbourhood Policy is the conclusion and implementation of agreements involving the issue of free trade – DCFTA agreements. These are of the utmost importance in the EU’s bilateral trade policy and in line with our efforts to achieve a stable, transparent and predictable economic environment. They are also fundamental in the fight against protectionism at a global level. They also reach far beyond trade issues and influence the state of democracy and the rule of law. I believe it is important to focus on the gradual dismantling of trade barriers, the strengthening of investment protection, the streamlining of customs and border procedures and the restriction of technical barriers to trade. The Eastern partnership countries are our strategic partners and, in this context, efforts to prevent conflicts by means of economic and social cohesion must be one of our priorities.

 
  
 		 

  Juozas Imbrasas (EFD), in writing. – (LT) I voted in favour of this report on the trade aspects of the Eastern partnership because the prospect of creating Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas (DCFTAs) with the EU is one of the key incentives for the partner countries to pursue their reform efforts. I believe that the creation of DCFTAs is one of the most ambitious tools of EU bilateral trade policy for achieving a stable, transparent and predictable economic environment which respects democracy, fundamental rights and the rule of law, providing not only for greater economic integration by a gradual dismantling of trade barriers, but also for regulatory convergence in areas that have an impact on trade in goods and services, in particular, by strengthening investment protection, streamlining customs and border procedures, reducing technical and other non-tariff barriers to trade, strengthening sanitary and phytosanitary rules, improving animal welfare, enhancing the legal frameworks for competition and public procurement and ensuring sustainable development.

 
  
 		 

  Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D), in writing. – (RO) Trade is a vitally important aspect of the EU’s relations with the countries in the Eastern partnership. Trade agreements are crucial instruments for building long-term economic relations with our Eastern partners and help promote economic reforms, the rule of law and social and environmental standards on our doorstep. I think that our Eastern partners cannot achieve economic integration with the EU effectively without political and social reforms and without civil society being involved in the decision-making process and economic integration being achieved even among the Eastern partners, a point actually emphasised as well by the report. The report also notes that national parliaments have an important role to play as well in harmonising trade legislation with the EU acquis, which is a prerequisite for concluding and implementing future agreements properly. There are countries in the Eastern partnership which have made remarkable progress, such as the Republic of Moldova. The report recognises with satisfaction that Moldova, despite the fragility of its economy, has, in recent years, undergone a remarkable reform process and hugely improved its economic performance. This highlights, in this regard, the vital importance of the financial assistance provided by the International Monetary Fund and the macro-financial assistance provided by the EU. These are some of the reasons why I support this report.

 
  
 		 

  Philippe Juvin (PPE), in writing. – (FR) For the majority of its neighbours, the European Union is the main export market and the main source of imports. This trade in goods and services plays a significant role in economic growth. The conclusion of ambitious European Union agreements with these countries is therefore essential. Hence, the most suitable and most effective method for strengthening these trade links is to establish a free trade area. The report provides for the gradual dismantling of trade barriers and seeks to bring about convergence of trade-related regulations. I voted in favour of this report.

 
  
 		 

  Michał Tomasz Kamiński (ECR), in writing. – (PL) I endorsed this report because I am firmly convinced that the prospect of opening Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas with the EU is the main incentive for partner countries to continue reforms. In recent years, Moldova has been through an exceptional series of reforms and has taken far-reaching steps towards European integration. I would also like to mention Georgia, one of the fastest-reforming economies in the world. Georgia is in a very specific situation as regards DCFTA negotiations and certain requirements and regulations laid down by the Commission. The Georgians have – in many cases quite rightly – closed down many bodies which had responsibility for oversight and inspection, as these were perceived as remnants of the Soviet system. This means that what the EU says are institutions which monitor standards often seem to the Georgians to be the corrupt legacy of Communism. The EU is Belarus’s second largest trading partner after Russia. It is true that our eastern neighbour has undoubted potential. I am certain that Belarusian citizens deserve to belong to the European family of democratic and free market states. Unfortunately, Minsk is moving ever further away from the EU in terms of political and economic standards. Furthermore, the Belarusian economic model, in which 80% of enterprises are owned by the state, leaves a great deal to be desired. So, when we are talking about Belarus and the commercial aspect of the Eastern partnership, a DCFTA, unfortunately, has to be put off to another day.

 
  
 		 

  Giovanni La Via (PPE), in writing. – (IT) Trade relations with the EU’s Eastern partners are an important aspect of our economic policies and must be carefully monitored in order to allow for their improvement. In particular, the creation of Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas (DCFTAs) in the east represents a basket of economic and trade opportunities, with multiple implications for our operators, in particular, small and medium-sized enterprises and the tourism industry, provided that reciprocity is respected in important areas such as compliance with the same rules on security and control. It is clear that through the creation of free trade areas, we want to act not only at the economic level but also at the political and social levels of the countries involved in the trade partnership. There is no doubt that, in order to achieve a proper industrial development strategy, we must first implement cooperation aimed at improving the civil and political characteristics that can allow for the maximum expression of individual freedom.

 
  
 		 

  Petru Constantin Luhan (PPE), in writing. – (RO) With regard to the trade aspects of the whole Eastern partnership, establishing Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas (DCFTAs) with the EU will definitely produce tangible long-term benefits for all stakeholders. However, I think that the measures for some key sectors of activity supporting these states’ economic development must be examined and regulated more widely from the perspective of the EU’s policies, such as the SME sector and research and innovation. I am concerned about the unstable political and economic situation in some of the states in the region, which needs to be closely monitored. This is why I think that we need to be cautious but, at the same time, continue the steps involving the flexible economic arrangements given to the relevant countries, as well as the institutional support.

 
  
 		 

  Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE), in writing. – (PL) The report on the trade aspects of the Eastern partnership is about important international issues, and it underscores efforts to strengthen the Eastern partnership countries. Personally, I think that trade agreements, apart from the fact that they impose conditions on the respective parties, also bring many benefits. By stimulating economic growth, they provide benefits to consumers, businesses and employees, and they also stimulate institutional reforms, which, in consequence, lead to the modernisation of entire countries and regions.

As a member of the EU-Ukraine delegation, I would like to stress that Ukraine is Europe’s largest trading partner among the Eastern partnership countries and we should support the efforts being made by Ukrainian society and the country’s authorities to eliminate all social and political inequalities. For this reason, among others, I voted in favour of the Ransdorf report.

 
  
 		 

  Monica Luisa Macovei (PPE), in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that we must show our support to the countries of the Eastern partnership. The creation of Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas is a key incentive for democratisation. People who can trade more freely will discover on their own the advantages of a political system based on respect for the rule of law and democratic values. I also welcome the Commission’s proposal to increase by 40% the funding available for the eastern neighbourhood policy in the multiannual financial framework 2014-2021. We need to spend European taxpayers’ money in an effective way and reward high achievers. The Republic of Moldova has made considerable progress in the past year. This would not have been possible without the EU’s support. We need to continue our negotiations with the Eastern partners and open up new economic possibilities for their citizens. Financial support, free trade and strong conditionality are the tools the Union should use in promoting our values in the neighbourhood.

 
  
 		 

  David Martin (S&D), in writing. – I voted for this resolution, which ‘is convinced that the economic integration of the Eastern partners with the EU cannot be efficiently carried out without political and social reforms, participation of civil society in the decision-making process and economic integration among the Eastern partners themselves; emphasises that economic integration among these countries should be open, so as to capitalise on its benefits; regrets in this regard that regional frozen conflicts have, for many years, harmed the effectiveness and development of cross-border trade and continue to cause enormous economic losses to some of the Eastern partners and to lead to their economic isolation’.

 
  
 		 

  Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (CS) I would like to welcome the fact that this report has directed the European Parliament’s attention in relation to the Eastern partnership programme towards the practical side of our mutual relations in the area of the economy and trade. Even though the original version opened up and exacerbated the difference in ideological approaches less, the final version of the report is a good step towards improving our relations. Unfortunately, it completely failed to avoid formulations that amount to double standards when it comes to assessing Eastern partnership countries. It is important that the WTO accession talks are emphasised. In my opinion, however, it is more important to be able to make use of the benefits arising from cooperation with Belarus, Russia and Kazakhstan, which have created a functional customs union. Turning our backs on this partnership would mean significant losses for the EU in the future.

 
  
 		 

  Clemente Mastella (PPE), in writing. – (IT) The creation of Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas is, without a doubt, one of the most ambitious tools of EU bilateral trade policy for achieving a stable, transparent and predictable economic environment which, at the same time, respects democracy, fundamental rights and the rule of law.

By adopting this report, we wish to emphasise the importance of the comprehensive institution building programme, technical assistance and information exchange instrument (TAIEX) with our Eastern partners. In the long run, the benefits of such integration will compensate for the initial efforts: the support and involvement of local civil society and international NGOs in promoting the long-term benefits is key for the success of their reform processes.

We are in favour of strengthening cooperation between the EU and its Eastern partners in a number of sectors, in particular, industry, small and medium-sized enterprises, research, development and innovation, and tourism. The economic integration of the Eastern partners with the EU cannot be efficiently carried out without political and social reforms, participation of civil society in the decision-making process and economic integration among the Eastern partners themselves.

 
  
 		 

  Véronique Mathieu (PPE), in writing. – (FR) I voted in favour of the report on the trade aspects of the Eastern partnership because trade agreements with the EU’s neighbours, in other words, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, will support growth by providing mutual benefits. To create free trade areas, we have to work towards a greater convergence of our partners’ regulations with European standards.

 
  
 		 

  Marek Henryk Migalski (ECR), in writing. – (PL) I endorsed the Ransdorf report because it underscores the application of the ‘more for more’ principle in the EU’s relations with the Eastern partnership countries. The report also stresses that Russia has undermined trade negotiations between the EU and several Eastern partners, and that this will be counterproductive in the long run for these countries. I agree with this view. In my opinion, we should make good use of the fact that the Union is the main export partner of the Eastern partnership countries. It should, however, be said that effective economic integration of the Eastern partners with the EU is not possible without political and social reforms or without the participation of civil society in the decision-making process.

 
  
 		 

  Alexander Mirsky (S&D), in writing. – Trade is a very important component of the EU’s relations with the Eastern partnership countries. Deep and comprehensive free trade agreements are vital instruments for building up long-term economic ties with our Eastern partners and are important tools for fostering economic reform, the rule of law and social and environmental standards in our neighbourhood. Furthermore, it is necessary to cooperate with all organisations where eastern neighbourhood countries are members.

 
  
 		 

  Andreas Mölzer (NI), in writing. – (DE) I agree with the point made in the motion for a resolution that the Arab Spring has put the spotlight on the EU’s southern neighbours in recent months and that we must not allow the importance of the Eastern partnership to be overshadowed by this. From an historic perspective, we have stronger links with the eastern countries and they are generally closer to us in cultural terms. In the light of China’s constantly growing economic influence in the countries of the Eastern partnership, I doubt whether concluding and implementing the association agreement, including the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas (DCFTAs), should be a high priority and an important requirement for the revised European Neighbourhood Policy with regard to our Eastern partners. We should not forget Russia’s historic sphere of influence in this respect. An approach of this kind could rapidly become an own goal with regard to our ongoing energy dependency. Therefore, I have voted against this motion for a resolution.

 
  
 		 

  Radvilė Morkūnaitė-Mikulėnienė (PPE), in writing. – (LT) I voted in favour. With this document, the European Parliament has again expressed its support for the European aspirations and reforms of the countries of the Eastern partnership (EaP). The EU is not only aiming to establish an area of close political cooperation but a stable, transparent and predictable area of economic cooperation. Mutual efforts are required to establish such a trade area and I am therefore pleased that in many respects, things are moving forward as regards the conclusion of DCFTA agreements. Trade policy is one of the most effective instruments for promoting reforms. It is not an aid instrument and it is therefore very important for EaP countries to continue to make every effort to facilitate the conclusion of such agreements. On the other hand, tendencies contrary to the EU’s goals are being observed in this region. It is regrettable that to some, it still seems that an area of stability, transparency, sustainable development and democracy goes against someone’s interests.

 
  
 		 

  Rareş-Lucian Niculescu (PPE), in writing. – (RO) I voted in favour of the report, particularly because it contains a number of vitally important references to trade relations with the Eastern states in the agricultural sector. One of these references relates to the process of implementing the EU’s sanitary and plant protection measures which would guarantee partner states the opportunity to export agricultural products to the EU without disadvantaging European farmers. This is the only way to allow the trade relationship in the agricultural sector between the EU and third countries to operate, if the same rules apply to everyone.

 
  
 		 

  Siiri Oviir (ALDE), in writing. – (ET) I believe that the development of trade between the European Union and the countries of the Eastern partnership is of great importance. The latter countries have 75 million inhabitants, and I therefore supported the proposals contained in this report. The establishment of free trade areas would certainly be an effective measure in the development of long-term economic relations. The gradual removal of trade barriers will increase economic integration and help to harmonise the legal framework in areas that influence trade in goods and services. Economic integration between the European Union and the countries of the Eastern partnership will also provide a significant stimulus to the implementation of democratic reforms in those countries. For Europe, cooperation with the countries of the Eastern partnership is of great economic and political importance.

 
  
 		 

  Rolandas Paksas (EFD), in writing. – (LT) I welcome this resolution because a comprehensive free trade area can only function on the basis of close and credible cooperation. In order to phase out trade barriers, it is necessary for partner countries to properly meet the conditions laid down. There should be a particular focus on the implementation of democracy, the principles of the rule of law and human rights. Furthermore, investment protection must be strengthened and customs and other administrative procedures streamlined. This would be a significant boost for changes to harmonise regulation and remove tariff and other barriers.

 
  
 		 

  Justas Vincas Paleckis (S&D), in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because it provides a comprehensive analysis of the strong and weak aspects of trade relations with the EU’s Eastern partners and outlines necessary developments in this field.

The EU has supported the progress of democracy and the market economy in partner countries in the East since the very beginning of their independence. Sustainable and transparent relations with these countries are in the utmost interest of the EU, and DCFTAs are an appropriate tool to achieve it.

Still, good implementation remains the challenge. Further progress has to be merit-driven. I share the rapporteur’s concerns about competition with Russia in the region. The EU should strengthen partnership relations with Russia and not offer two alternative paths for the eastern neighbourhood partners.

I regret that Belarus consistently fails to be involved in European integration. I hope that the EU will find new instruments and approaches to initiate political change in the country and its rapprochement towards EU standards.

 
  
 		 

  Maria do Céu Patrão Neves (PPE), in writing. – (PT) I voted in favour, as I agree with the statements made in this resolution, as well as Parliament’s proposal that these be taken into consideration by the Council, the Commission and the European External Action Service during the negotiation and execution of the trade sections of the association agreements with Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, as well as the development of trade relations between the EU and Belarus.

 
  
 		 

  Aldo Patriciello (PPE), in writing. – (IT) The creation of a Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area with the EU is, for our partner countries, one of the main incentives to pursue their reforms. It in fact represents one of the most ambitious tools of EU bilateral trade policy for achieving a stable, transparent and predictable economic environment which respects democracy, fundamental rights and the rule of law. This would provide not only for greater economic integration by a gradual dismantling of trade barriers but also for regulatory convergence in areas that have an impact on trade in goods and services, in particular, by strengthening investment protection, streamlining customs and border procedures, and reducing technical and other non-tariff barriers to trade. Taking into account the fact that greater trade integration requires significant short-term and medium-term efforts by our Eastern partners, I voted in favour in order to create favourable political and regulatory conditions for the development of trade relations with eastern countries.

 
  
 		 

  Paulo Rangel (PPE), in writing. – (PT) Most countries neighbouring the EU, in particular, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, have the EU as their main export market and source of imports. Trade in goods and services is a powerful tool for stimulating economic growth, increasing competitiveness and supporting economic recovery, while also influencing the state of democracy and strengthening the rule of law. In this context, the conclusion and implementation of association agreements, including Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas (DCFTAs), are a priority objective and aim of the European Neighbourhood Policy with regard to its Eastern partners. However, the success of the DCFTAs will depend largely on the institutional strengthening and proper implementation of commitments, which can only be ensured in an environment of open, transparent and corruption-free negotiation. In view of this, and despite the progress already made, it is vital that the Eastern partners commit to undertaking all necessary institutional and structural reforms.

 
  
 		 

  Jean Roatta (PPE), in writing. – (FR) For the majority of the European Union’s neighbours, in other words, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, the EU is the main export market and the main source of imports. Therefore, the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area is the most important and most effective instrument at our disposal for strengthening our trade links. The gradual dismantling of trade barriers and regulatory convergence in areas that have an impact on trade are rightly included in this Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area. Beyond the economic aspect, free trade areas can be a core component of a wider political agreement, leading, in particular, to an association agreement. The rapporteur also stresses that, with the signature of agreements and the creation of the free trade area, the European Union might also provide its assistance and strengthen the role of civil society or even steer reforms, both in the public and private sectors. My vote in favour of the Ransdorf report applauds its social and democratic goals, which are fundamental aspects of our partnerships.

 
  
 		 

  Raül Romeva i Rueda (Verts/ALE), in writing. – Against. We asked for a split vote to eliminate paragraph 4, which says that trade agreements should be negotiated even if it is ‘not possible or advisable to conclude an association agreement with a particular third country’. As this was not done, we voted against.

 
  
 		 

  Matteo Salvini (EFD), in writing. – (IT) Mr Ransdorf’s report seems balanced. This is why I have voted in favour. The EU should become an increasingly privileged partner for this area, especially for the time, which I hope will soon come, when ethnic and religious tensions finally give way to development and prosperity for the peoples in the Caucasus region. Europe can do much in this regard.

 
  
 		 

  Sergio Paolo Francesco Silvestris (PPE), in writing. – (IT) The conclusion and implementation of association agreements, including Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas, is a priority aim and ambition of the reviewed European Neighbourhood Policy regarding the Eastern partners. Following the revolutionary movements which took place in 2011 in the EU southern neighbourhood, known as the Arab Spring, Europe’s interest has also been focused on the southern neighbours. With this vote, we therefore urge the Commission to take such considerations and recommendations into due account during the negotiations and implementation of the trade-related aspects of the association agreements with Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, as well as in developing trade relations between the EU and Belarus. We also call on the Commission to report to Parliament at regular intervals and in detail on the progress of the negotiations.

 
  
 		 

  Marc Tarabella (S&D), in writing. – (FR) Helping democracy and preventing conflicts in the European neighbourhood. Those are the main reasons why I support this resolution. However, we cannot accept just anything. That is why, in order to establish free trade areas in the long term, we are calling on these countries to align their national legislation with EU standards, enabling us to make ‘specific recommendations’ for each of them.

 
  
 		 

  Nuno Teixeira (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The conclusion and implementation of association agreements, including Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas, are a priority objective and aim of the European Neighbourhood Policy with regard to its Eastern partners. Parliament has expressed its support for stepping up cooperation between the EU and its Eastern partners in several areas, in particular, industry, small and medium-sized enterprises, research, development and innovation, information and communications technology and tourism, and considers differentiation accompanied by the ‘more for more’ principle, under the European Neighbourhood Policy, a step in the right direction towards the development of trade relations with its Eastern partners. I voted for the report for these reasons.

 
  
 		 

  Silvia-Adriana Ţicău (S&D), in writing. – (RO) I voted for the report on the trade aspects of the Eastern partnership. Concluding and implementing association agreements, including Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas (DCFTAs), is a priority aim of the European Neighbourhood Policy regarding the Eastern partners. I welcome the efforts made towards strengthening the Eastern partnership, especially the Commission’s initiatives on SMEs, including the facility granted to SMEs based on the Eastern partnership. I think that the main benefits which the EU will gain from implementing the DCFTA will be more stable and predictable trade. For example, Ukraine is the EU’s largest Eastern partner and the DCFTA opens up a new market of 46 million consumers for the EU. I should stress the importance of Moldova continuing to align with the EU its energy infrastructure and systems for technical regulation, standardisation, conformity assessment, testing and market surveillance. I welcome the Commission proposal on the multiannual financial framework 2014-2020, proposing a 40% rise in the funding available to the European neighbourhood policy. Our Eastern partners cannot bear the costs of legislative harmonisation and the necessary institutional and structural reforms by themselves, and EU financial support should complement their reform efforts.

 

8. Corrections to votes and voting intentions: see Minutes
 

(The sitting was suspended at 14.55 and resumed at 15.05)

 
  
  

IN THE CHAIR: ANNI PODIMATA
Vice-President

 

9. Approval of the minutes of the previous sitting
Video of the speeches
 

  President. – The minutes of yesterday’s sitting have been distributed.

Are there any comments?

 
  
 

  Franz Obermayr (NI). – (DE) Madam President, before the start of this very important and interesting debate, I would like to ask a fundamental question about the procedure by making a statement to you, which I hope will receive an appropriate answer.

I have a great deal of understanding and sympathy for the activists who are opposed to the Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement (ACTA) and for their activities. However, for me, it is not just about this. I would like you to explain whether in future, Parliament will allow leafleting campaigns to be carried out for all the relevant items on the agenda by guests who are visiting Parliament. It is important for us to resolve this and to have a suitable answer, so that we know in future how we as Members should behave and how groups who have a point to make about a specific subject should behave. I would be grateful if you could clarify the situation and give me an appropriate answer, not necessarily today, but in the near future.

 
  
 

  President. – Thank you very much Mr Obermayr, your comment has been noted. As an initial response, I must say that, as far as the distribution of leaflets outside the Chamber is concerned, there is no particular problem in principle. We have not identified any infringements of the Rules of Procedure in connection with the distribution of leaflets. Thus, in principle, the Bureau considers that there is no problem. However, I can assure you that we shall investigate this matter further.

(The minutes of the previous sitting were approved)

 

10. Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement between the EU and its Member States, Australia, Canada, Japan, the Republic of Korea, Mexico, Morocco, New Zealand, Singapore, Switzerland and the USA (debate)
Video of the speeches
 

  President. – The first item is the recommendation by David Martin, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, Australia, Canada, Japan, the Republic of Korea, the United Mexican States, the Kingdom of Morocco, New Zealand, the Republic of Singapore, the Swiss Confederation and the United States of America (12195/2011 - C7-0027/2012 - 2011/0167(NLE)) (A7-0204/2012).

 
  
 

  David Martin, rapporteur. – Madam President, today, my strong recommendation to this House is that we reject the ACTA Treaty.

At the outset of this debate though, let me make it clear that, unlike some, I do not criticise the Commission for bringing forward this proposal. It is their role as the institution with the right of initiative to do so. But the role of Parliament has been strengthened under the Lisbon Treaty and it is our job to scrutinise international agreements and to give them or deny them our consent.

Over the last three or four months, I have carefully studied the text. I have spoken to the officials who have negotiated this agreement. I have spoken to the rights holders that it seeks to protect, and I have engaged with civil society organisations who have serious concerns about this agreement.

I personally have come to the conclusion that there are serious flaws and serious concerns about the way that this agreement could be misinterpreted and implemented. Therefore, as rapporteur, I cannot recommend that the Parliament gives it its approval.

Before, I have described myself as the accidental rapporteur. I genuinely came to this report with no agenda on ACTA and, if anything, I was probably regarded as having a pro-IPR agenda. I know of authors and musicians who are far from wealthy and who depend on the protection of their creations to make a living.

As I have said before, creativity is the raw material of the European Union. In September 2011, we were here debating the EU 2020 strategy and the future of trade policy. Protecting European intellectual property is a key part of that. We cannot compete globally as a low-wage economy and we should not try. Protecting our innovation and creative industries is vital for job creation and for economic recovery.

But this is not a vote about the general importance of IPR. It is a vote on the text of the ACTA Treaty. I have listened to civil society’s concerns on this agreement and, while some of the perceived threats of ACTA were perhaps exaggerated or unfounded, I am convinced that there are some key problems with the treaty.

The first is a lack of clear definition of ‘commercial scale’. ACTA refers to ‘commercial activities for direct or indirect economic or commercial advantage’. But what exactly is ‘indirect commercial advantage’. What if one person copies a piece of music or a film and gives it to a friend, who gives it to another friend, and so on. Is that ‘commercial scale’, or is that simple private usage? I know the Commission will say that it is not ‘commercial scale’ because commercial scale is defined in European law. But ‘commercial scale’ is not defined in the ACTA Treaty.

It is also possible that ACTA could unintentionally criminalise individuals if we do not have a clear and precise definition of ‘commercial scale’. I also have related concerns to the sanctions contained in the ACTA Treaty which appear sometimes to be excessive in terms of the civil and criminal penalties.

The third major area of concern I have is the role of Internet service providers (ISPs). Provisions which might push ISPs to monitor online behaviour and report individuals for IPR infringement is very dangerous. It is not the role of ISPs to police the Internet, and we should not be privatising law enforcement in this way.

We have had many debates in this Chamber on international agreements. I have often said that the devil is in the detail. This time, the devil is in the lack of detail. Rights holders in the creative and manufacturing industries are voracious in pursuing their rights, often understandably so when you see the level of counterfeit and piracy they face.

But this means that a vague text is dangerous. We cannot guarantee that civil liberties will be robustly protected by the ACTA Treaty provisions. When it comes down to protecting intellectual property rights or protecting civil liberties, civil liberties should always be central to the concern of this House. The freedom of the Internet is highly valued by our citizens and we interfere with that at our peril.

(Applause)

 
  
 

  Karel De Gucht, Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, tomorrow, you will have to make a choice. It is an important choice for at least two reasons. Firstly, because the debate over the Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement has involved much discussion of its relationship with the fundamental rights and freedoms of European citizens. Secondly, because of the signal this vote will send to our trading partners and to the more than 120 million workers that work in Europe’s innovative, manufacturing and creative sectors. They are dependent for their livelihoods on the effective enforcement of intellectual property rights, in Europe and across the rest of the world.

The Commission has asked the European Court of Justice for its opinion on whether the Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement is compatible with the treaties and, in particular, with our Charter of Fundamental Rights. We have done this because these questions are crucial for those who took to the streets over ACTA earlier this year. We share their view that these concerns must be addressed. That is why the ACTA agreement should be the subject of the most careful scrutiny and deliberation.

In this respect, I believe that it would have been preferable for Parliament to wait until we know what the Court thinks before voting. But that is not where we are today. Tomorrow, you will only be able to choose to vote ‘yes’ or ‘no’ to the agreement. Let me then just say that my considered view, as a lifelong supporter of human rights and fundamental freedoms, is that there is nothing to fear in this agreement.

ACTA is not an attack on our liberties, it is a defence of our livelihoods. This is because we do not have to modify any part of our internal legislation, the so-called acquis communautaire. What is legal today in the European Union will remain legal once ACTA is ratified. And what is illegal today will still remain illegal with ACTA. Nothing changes in the eyes of the law. And since our freedoms are not threatened by our current laws, our freedoms will not be threatened by ACTA. This is also – I might add – the view of the European Parliament’s own Legal Service. I hope that you will bear these considerations in mind.

Economic consequences are the second reason the vote is important. We all agree that counterfeiting and piracy are a serious problem. They risk undermining one of Europe’s most significant competitive advantages over other regions of the world, namely, our knowledge-based and creative industries. ACTA is designed to extend the tools for enforcement of intellectual property rights that have been so successful in Europe – and which this Parliament has always supported – to other countries as well. No more. No less.

So, as you come to make your choice about how to vote tomorrow, you should also make no mistake: a vote against ACTA will be a setback for the protection of our intellectual property rights around the world. Neither are there any quick fixes for its rejection. Those who think that we can come back any time soon with a revised agreement or with a new treaty have been misled. What is true is that, if Parliament votes this treaty down, the Commission will continue to wait for the opinion of the Court and study it closely. Why? Because citizens have raised concerns over its potential impact on fundamental rights, because many of you have raised similar questions – so let us get some answers.

I consider it my obligation, my responsibility as European Commissioner – indeed the responsibility of us all – to ask for clarity from Europe’s highest court. Furthermore, we will also look at how the debate on intellectual property rights evolves over the coming months. There are legitimate issues to be discussed and clarified about some rules on intellectual property rights in the digital environment. For instance, the definition of ‘commercial scale’ and what sharing information means in relation to the challenges one faces with respect to the protection of intellectual property.

I hope that these discussions will be able to happen in their proper context – which is in debates about the substantive law of the European Union, not about international enforcement.

Besides the European Parliament, the Commission would also discuss the outcome of the Court referral with other signatories of ACTA and would then consider further steps to take.

As Europeans, I believe that we all share profound respect for individual freedom. But I also know that freedom needs a framework. What we are doing both with ACTA and with European legislation is making sure that the framework strikes the right balance. It is a delicate task and we must proceed carefully.

 
  
 

  Jan Zahradil, rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Development. – (CS) Madam President, I find myself in a peculiar situation as rapporteur for the Committee on Development because the committee has adopted an opposite opinion to the one I proposed as rapporteur.

The Committee favoured a negative position on this agreement. I, as rapporteur, was more favourable towards it, but I have to respect the majority opinion, of course.

However, I must add a few comments on this. In my opinion, there is a clear majority in this Parliament that simply wants to reject this agreement, and for a variety of reasons. I have to say it is rather illogical that Parliament has decided not to wait for the opinion of the European Court of Justice on the compatibility of this agreement with European primary law. I frankly do not understand this, and I would consider it far more logical to wait.

I take things as they are, however, and since the Committee on Development has adopted a negative opinion, I have no option as rapporteur but to reproduce that opinion here.

 
  
 

  Amelia Andersdotter, rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. – (SV) Madam President, I would like to say thank you to all my fellow Members and everyone listening out there in Europe. For those of us who have been involved in the information policy debate for a long time, the decision that this House will take tomorrow is not only symbolic of what is right and proper in the information age, it is also crucial for European democracy.

Communication and culture build societies. It is no surprise, therefore, that ACTA was the issue that generated the pan-European debate that caught our attention and that caused many people to consider how we as a society actually want to deal with communication.

It was on this very issue that I and many others in my political party, the Pirate Party, found a reason for our involvement in politics. The problem is that the agreement does not change anything. We need more access to culture and communication. How do we actually want to relate to other people? How do we build a sense of community and familiarity with other people?

All of us who consider these questions and who are helping to build these communities hope that Parliament will be strong when it takes the decision tomorrow – we hope that Parliament will listen to all of Europe’s citizens when they speak with one voice because our societies need to be founded on the values of the citizens. It is clear that citizens’ values involve making communication and cultural exchange a priority and an opportunity for the future, and that is something that I and my political group here in Parliament, together with many other colleagues from other political groups, will recognise in the votes tomorrow.

 
  
 

  Evelyn Regner, rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs. – (DE) Madam President, Mr De Gucht, first of all, the purpose of the Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement (ACTA) is a good one and involves establishing international standards to combat breaches of copyright and product piracy. However, ACTA is a prime example of how we should not be dealing with the justified concerns of citizens, in other words, with a lack of transparency that has to be seen to be believed.

There are many serious reservations about ACTA. The Committee on Legal Affairs has taken these reservations into account and has made clear its opposition to ACTA. The intention of the agreement is to intervene in data protection and, therefore, in the right to informational self-determination. The agreement is too vague and, as a result, I am concerned that it may be implemented differently in the relevant states, which will be to the detriment of our citizens.

I am opposed to Internet service providers being able to monitor citizens and, under certain circumstances, actually doing so. I am concerned that the necessary renewal of copyright in Europe will be restricted and forestalled under pressure from the industry. This is why we must say a clear ‘No’ to ACTA tomorrow.

 
  
 

  Dimitrios Drousas, rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. – (EL) Madam President, we acknowledge and respect fully the need for artists to be protected and to be compensated for their genius and the challenges posed by current technology when it comes to achieving this. However, we must not accept and cannot allow basic fundamental rights in Europe and the rest of the world to be eroded. The European Union – and I must emphasise this – has established very high levels of protection for fundamental rights and the European Parliament must be in the front line of efforts to maintain those high levels, for the benefit, as always, of European citizens.

It is precisely within this spirit that we arrived in our opinion at the conclusion that ACTA is not compatible with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, especially in light of its ambiguity. We therefore recommend that the House reject this ambiguous agreement.

However, I would like to underline this: rejection of ACTA should not mark the end of the affair. It should mark the beginning of proper public debate involving all interested parties, in order to arrive at a modern social agreement and regime for protecting intellectual property rights.

 
  
 

  Christofer Fjellner, on behalf of the PPE Group. – (SV) Madam President, tomorrow we will vote on the Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement and I would like to start by making it clear what I and the Group of the European People’s Party (Christian Democrats) think about this.

We need international cooperation in order to defend intellectual property rights, to put a stop to counterfeit medicines and vehicle parts, to stop violations of European patents and piracy of European products and to safeguard Europe’s competitiveness. ACTA is a good basis for this work.

It would, however, be irresponsible to vote on ACTA tomorrow – to take a position before we have all of the cards on the table and before the European Court of Justice has issued its opinion on the agreement. This is not a reasonable and responsible way to deal with this issue. I would like to ask all those who are opposed to waiting for the Court of Justice just one thing: why? What is it that you are so afraid the Court of Justice will say that you feel it is necessary, at all costs, to vote before the EU’s highest judicial body has expressed its opinion?

Tomorrow’s vote is not just about ACTA. It is about patient safety, research, air safety, competitiveness, the environment, job security, etc., as these areas are all affected by piracy, patent violations and counterfeiting.

Therefore, voting ‘no’ tomorrow carries a great deal of responsibility. It may perhaps resolve the conflict regarding ACTA, but it will not represent a solution to the problems and challenges that Europe is facing. Voting ‘no’ will not maintain the status quo either. It will weaken Europe’s voice on the world stage. How are we to be able to convince India to take forceful action against counterfeit medicines if we ourselves have rejected European or international cooperation based on our own legislation?

It is no surprise to me that those in this House who do not want intellectual property rights or who do not believe we should protect intellectual property rights will vote against ACTA before we have the Court’s opinion, in the same way as it is no surprise that someone who does not want Europe to fight against climate change does not want the Kyoto Protocol either. However, I do not believe that reflects the opinion of the majority of us in this House, and therefore I hope you will not want to put an end to ACTA before we have all the cards on the table. Why is that? Well, we need international cooperation on intellectual property rights in order to protect European jobs, consumers, patients, etc. That is why we should not discard ACTA tomorrow.

(The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 149(8))

 
  
 

  Marc Tarabella (S&D), Blue-card question. – (FR) Madam President, I have a question for Mr Fjellner. I did not want to take the floor at this point in the debate. It is a question that I wanted to put to Commissioner De Gucht, perhaps. He will undoubtedly have the opportunity to answer me shortly, at the end of the debate. However, mentioning today that we are waiting for the opinion of the Court of Justice is a delaying tactic and, furthermore, I would like to know if you think it is normal for the Commissioner to ask for the opinion of the Court of Justice after negotiating the treaty? Is it normal to wonder at the end of the road whether the treaty complies with other laws, particularly those on individual liberties?

 
  
 

  President. – Thank you, Mr Tarabella, but you know that, according to the Rules of Procedure, questions cannot be addressed to Commissioners. Was your question addressed to Mr Fjellner?

 
  
 

  Christofer Fjellner (PPE), Blue-card answer. – (SV) It would have been nice if you had also answered the question as to why you are in such a hurry to carry out this vote, and why you cannot consider waiting to hear whether or not ACTA is compatible with the Treaty. I have listened to citizens, and the main objections that I have received concern privacy and fundamental civil rights and freedoms, and that is what the Commission has asked about. Therefore, for us to wait for the answer is, I think, to give the matter its due respect.

(The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 149(8))

 
  
 

  Jörg Leichtfried (S&D), Blue-card question. – (DE) Madam President, Mr Fjellner, now I am disappointed. Why can you not be honest about this? The Group of the European People’s Party (Christian Democrats) only wants to postpone the vote because it is actually in favour of the Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement (ACTA) and hopes that it will be able to push it through. That is the reason behind this. Please explain to me why you support the American film industry and not European Internet users. Just for your information, Mr Fjellner, ACTA will not be of any benefit at all to India, because India is not part of this agreement.

 
  
 

  Christofer Fjellner (PPE), Blue-card answer. – Madam President, I am trying to be perfectly honest with Mr Leichtfried. I said at the very outset we need international cooperation, and ACTA is a good basis for that.

However, the difference between you, Mr Leichtfried, and me is that I want to listen to the highest juridical court before I take this vote. I think that is acting seriously. I think the question would actually be the same to you. What are you afraid of? What are you afraid that the European Court of Justice will say which makes it so desperately important for you to vote before we have heard what they say? That is actually my question.

 
  
 

  Jörg Leichtfried (S&D). – (DE) Madam President, please could you enlighten me? Mr Fjellner has asked me a question. Am I allowed to answer it or not? I am not sure what I should do. All I would like to say to him is that ACTA is not a legal issue, it is a political issue, which will be decided on by us and not by some court or other.

(Applause)

 
  
 

  Bernd Lange, on behalf of the S&D Group. – (DE) Madam President, Mr De Gucht, ladies and gentlemen, this is a political issue on which we have to decide. We in the Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament have analysed the Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement (ACTA) very closely and carefully, and we would like to make it clear that ACTA is not a suitable instrument for guaranteeing copyright protection and preventing counterfeiting. ACTA is the wrong instrument for this and, therefore, we in the S&D Group will be voting against it. Why is that? For three reasons.

Firstly, the countries which are mainly responsible for counterfeiting and disregarding copyright are not the subject of the agreement. The good have been sorted out from the bad and, in international terms, it makes absolutely no sense.

Secondly, ladies and gentlemen, rules from the analogue area of counterfeiting have been transferred into the digital world and, as a result, the wrong rules are being imposed on consumers who behave differently in a digital environment. This is why we are saying that we cannot put apples and pears into a saucepan and finish up with apple sauce. The wrong things are being combined here and that is the second reason why we are opposed to ACTA.

However, ladies and gentlemen, the most important reason is the third one. ACTA is putting the digital world into a straitjacket and we do not even know whether we want it, because the question of enforcing intellectual property rights on the Internet, in the digital environment, has not even been resolved within the European Union. The Commission’s presentation of its legislative proposal is overdue.
